urn:contentItem:5V71-6CC1-F14X-V546-00000-00Outlook 2019 Apparel industry challenges and opportunities2019-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisOutlook 2019 Apparel industry challenges and opportunitiesLeonie Barrie

It won't come as any surprise that uncertainty, complexity and volatility in the global economy, US-China trade and Brexit, along with rapidly changing consumption patterns, are pushing the global apparel industry and its supply chain into unchartered territory in the year ahead. But according to feedback from a panel of executives consulted by just-style, disruptions also present huge opportunities for retailers and brands to rethink their business models and explore new ways of working – especially when it comes to using new technologies and data.

Marc Compagnon, executive director & group president, Li & Fung:
The unpredictable geopolitical environment will be a major challenge facing our industry in 2019. The US-China trade war is on a lot of retailers' minds and has taken a few turns now, with costs starting to rise. Apparel companies must act fast and diversify production strategies to position themselves to absorb any shock from possible trade conflicts. With a global network of 15,000 suppliers in over 40 markets, Li & Fung is well positioned to help our customers diversify their sourcing portfolios to offset any impact from the trade war.

Trade aside, another challenge facing the apparel industry is keeping up with the pace of change with consumers. I think in 2019 we'll continue to see the retail sector pushed to the limits in keeping ahead of new technologies, the online effect, pressures from fast fashion retailers, increased complexities in the omnichannel world, and the growth of data. But these disruptions present huge opportunities for retailers and brands to rethink their business models and explore new ways of working, and engaging with their consumers.

Rick Helfenbein, president & CEO, American Apparel & Footwear Association (AAFA):
After ten tumultuous years, most of the retail and apparel/footwear sectors had finally seen the light of day by early 2018. The industry survived a string of bankruptcies, adjusted excess retail space, learned how to sell online, and welcomed the millennial shopper with open arms.

Just as relief was settling in, the next retail tsunami was unleashed by President Trump's tariff war with China. This single disruptive tariff action has put much of our industry in a tailspin. We now reside in uncharted supply chain territory given 41% of US apparel and 72% of US footwear originate in China. The mere threat of import tariffs – even more than the actual implementation – has left our industry in a difficult position.

Facing what can likely be characterised as the most disruptive dynamic sourcing shift in recent memory, apparel, footwear and accessory suppliers are vacating the comfort of their existing supply chains and venturing to countries somewhat untested and unknown to their confidence zone. The new cry from financial analysts to industry officials for 2019 is very clear: "What's your China exposure?"

Edwin Keh, CEO of the Hong Kong Research Institute of Textiles and Apparel (HKRITA), and lecturer at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania:
2019 will be full of uncertainties as we deal with country of origin challenges in the current trade uncertainties. While this will occupy lots of operational attention in the short term, there are also going to be long term challenges.

Now that we are coming up on 2020, all those promises the industry made about improving sustainability practices, transparency, and working conditions need to move from vague commitments to action and change. There are lots of companies who are woefully unprepared and, as result, risk losing credibility and consumer confidence.

As global consumption patterns shift from online to omni-channel, from developed Western countries to emerging Eastern economies (China and India), and from buying what is inexpensive (price) to buying what is valuable (innovative, meaningful, good), brands have to find deep and meaningful connections with their customers. They must also give them compelling reasons to consume, and finds ways to optimise their supply chains to create seamless, frictionless, customer centric user experiences. This will mean reshaping existing global supply chains, forging new alliances, and bringing on new talent and leadership.

Robert Antoshak, managing director, Olah Inc:
Many challenges are facing the global apparel industry – but that's nothing new! However, in 2019 there are three significant challenges worth considering. First, how best to reach an evolving customer; second, how to maximise sustainability initiatives to meet business objectives; and third, how to adapt to a rapidly changing sourcing environment.

Let's start with our customers. In many countries around the world, consumers are increasingly younger with less disposable income to spend on clothing than previous generations. Moreover, what financial resources these consumers do have may more likely be spent on the latest high-tech gadget than on the latest in denim or knitwear. Besides, many of these consumers are worried about how garments are made these days. And there are concerns over what happens to their clothes once they are discarded. As a result, supply chain transparency has become more important to more consumers.

Which brings me to sustainability. Although many consumers claim to support sustainable production in the apparel industry, many refuse to pay more for such initiatives simply because they can't afford it, which leaves brands in a pickle. Who's to pay? Sustainability comes with real costs that are either pushed upstream on suppliers or downstream to consumers, if not outright absorbed by brands (which is less likely). In any event, sustainable production remains essential to our industry and can be nurtured if it's supported by sound business practices.

And then there's the agony of today's sourcing brought to you by the US government. The trade war between the US and China has forced so many companies in our industry to reconsider their sourcing options – and fast. I mean now. The smart hedge for many companies seems to be in diversification. Long-established supply chains in China are hard to maintain when 25% tariffs are added to the mix. So other countries – led by Vietnam – have directly benefited as sourcing has shifted away from China. Additionally, some supply chains have shortened, too, to include sources of production closer to consuming markets. It will be interesting to see if such new sourcing patterns remain in place should the tariff war between the US and China ends suddenly.

Dr Sheng Lu, associate professor at the Department of Fashion and Apparel Studies at the University of Delaware:
In my view, uncertainty will remain the single biggest challenge facing the apparel industry in 2019, ranging from a more volatile global economy, the unpredictable outlook of the US-China trade talks to the various possible Brexit scenarios. While uncertainty creates exciting new research opportunities for scholars like me, it could be a big headache for companies seeking a foreseeable market environment to guide their future business plan and investments.   

Meanwhile, the increasing digitalisation of the apparel supply chain based on big-data tools and artificial intelligence (AI) technologies means a huge opportunity for fashion companies. Indeed, the apparel industry is quickly changing in nature – becoming ever more globalised, supply-chain based, technology-intensive and data-driven. Take talent recruitment as an example. In the 2018 US Fashion Industry Benchmarking Study, which I conducted in collaboration with the US Fashion Industry Association (USFIA), 68% of executives surveyed from leading US fashion brands and apparel retailers said they plan to hire more data scientists in the next five years. The advance of digital technologies and the smarter use of data should enable apparel companies to overcome market uncertainties better and improve many aspects of their businesses such as speed to market, operational efficiency and even sustainability.

Rajiv Sharma, group chief executive, Coats:
A key challenge is the increasing consumer pressure on sustainability, although every challenge also presents opportunity. Our industry can do more here: promoting a circular economy, products using less water during manufacturing, reducing the use of plastic, consuming less electricity etc – there is much more that can still be done.   

The evergreen challenge remains responding to changing consumer trends. Where do they like to buy? What do they want to wear? How much do they want to pay for it? Despite the more uncertain economic outlook, consumers are still spending but the value proposition needs to be right. Brands and retailers that stay close to their consumers are best positioned to understand them, quickly identify subtle changes in behaviour or demands, and then respond accordingly.  

Across Asia, particularly India and China, the middle class consumer base continues to grow. Those with a position in these markets will be well placed to take advantage of future opportunities.

Margin pressure across the industry continues to be high. This, coupled with mixed demand across geographies and segments, will create a push towards more creative solutions. The winners in 2019 will be those players that navigate through a market that is more uncertain, complex and volatile. Each player needs to find a solution that works for them. 'One size fits all' does not work in our industry.  

Julia Hughes, president, United States Fashion Industry Association (USFIA):
The obvious answer: tariffs, trade wars, and the uncertainty resulting from 2018's major upheavals in policy, politics, and global markets. The growing trade protectionism in the United States, as well as in Europe, will cause continued trade disruption in 2019, and for the foreseeable future.

Of course, we can't deny the fact that intellectual property theft and other unfair trade practices in China are major challenges, too – especially for the fashion industry. We agree with the Trump Administration on the need to find solutions to these challenges. However, higher tariffs, an extended trade war with our largest trading partner, and heightened tensions with allies around the world won't solve the problem; these tactics will only create more challenges for American businesses and consumers.

We're also concerned about slavery and human trafficking in supply chains, cyber attacks affecting businesses and consumers, climate change (and the need for everyone to do their part to tackle it), and how companies can keep up with the constantly evolving retail landscape.

Still, there are opportunities. If we think creatively about this new political world, there's a huge opportunity to engage with the Trump Administration as they work to negotiate new bilateral trade agreements, eliminate overly burdensome regulations on businesses, and create new jobs in the United States. Already, we've had some success. The US-Mexico-Canada Agreement, or the "New NAFTA," contains several helpful provisions for the industry.

We also see exciting opportunities to challenge the high tariffs on US imports of consumer products like apparel and footwear. And on the retail front, companies can take advantage of the low unemployment and high wages to grow their businesses, if they innovate and rethink their supply chains, their products, and their stores to deliver what consumers really want right now.

More good news is that we're seeing more and more that consumers, especially millennials and younger consumers, want to buy from sustainable, transparent brands – more evidence of the business case for working to tackle issues like human trafficking and climate change.

Matthijs Crietee, secretary general, International Apparel Federation (IAF):
The main challenge is to effectively put to use all of the digital technology that has become available to create stronger, smarter and more sustainable supply chains. A lot of waste, both figuratively and literally speaking, can still be taken out of the supply chain, but effective implementation of the technology requires involvement of the entire supply chain. This is complex, expensive and risky, therefore requiring strong leadership.

Another major challenge for the industry is to communicate its achievements, particularly in terms of sustainability, to start rebuilding trust. A number of industry initiatives are delivering, but consumers are still largely in the dark. Indicative of this problem is that the 'apparel and textiles as the second most polluting industry' myth is so pervasive.

Trust is also an issue within the supply chain, where real or perceived bad purchasing practices clash with the good intentions of brands or retailers' CSR departments. The IAF, with a membership of most major industry associations in all continents, will take a larger role in 2019, bringing together in dialogue players from across the supply chain, buyers and manufacturers, large and small. Trust building is hard work, but it is what this industry needs very badly, both internally and externally.

Siobhán Géhin, Kurt Salmon, part of Accenture Strategy:
2019 will see another year of accelerating change – in fact, change has become the new norm. Customer expectations are higher than ever, driven by the digital revolution and a plethora of hyper-convenient offers and services available to customers. Consumers are in control, and they are driving the agenda for apparel retailers and manufacturers. Consumers increasingly want the latest trend, now and on their terms.

An ever-increasing number of new market entrants cater to micro-niches such as sustainable clothing, comfortable work garments for professional women, personalised tees etc. meaning loyalty to established brands is declining, and incumbent players are subject to the "attack of the minnows" –multiple small players nibbling at their market share.

On top of this, we will see some challenging market conditions in mature markets in 2019, with unpredictability in the UK and the US in particular. The uncertainty around global trade terms, given the potential impact of Brexit and the US/China trade war, will certainly have an impact on supply chains and costs, and potentially on consumer demand.

Dr Achim Berg, senior partner at McKinsey & Company and co-leader of McKinsey's Apparel, Fashion & Luxury Group:
Volatility, uncertainty and shifts in the global economy continue to be the top challenges for global fashion executives. As key economic indicators begin trending downward, a number of other potentially destabilising reasons for caution lie ahead. In fact, 70% of the respondents to our BoF-McKinsey State of Fashion survey are concerned about the overall global macroeconomic outlook in 2019.

Online and omnichannel transformation continue to represent a major challenge for the fashion industry as well.

The challenge for 2019 that international fashion executives mentioned third most often is the speed at which consumer preferences are changing. In response, fashion companies are working to reduce lead times, increase flexibility, and improve their demand-forecasting capabilities. End-to-end digitisation and advanced analytics play an important role in these efforts.

Sustainability and transparency, long treated as the subjects of box-ticking exercises, are evolving into transformational features. In this year's survey, these topics were among the top four challenges mentioned by global industry executives for the first time.

Rick Horwitch, vice president and global retail lead for supply chain strategy at Bureau Veritas Consumer Products Services:
The biggest challenges – speed, digitization, trust and transparency – are also the biggest opportunities. The traditional Economics 101 model of Supply and Demand, is being replaced with Economics 101.v2 – Demand and Supply. Consumers have more choices than ever before. There are more opportunities than at any time in history for retailers, brands and manufacturers to collaborate with each other and directly with the consumer. The key is to create a collaborative value equation that addresses the entire product cycle (concept to consumer). We are living through an amazing retail renaissance.    

To meet this opportunity, long-standing business models, processes and thinking are changing.  The continuing push for speed, reduced inventories and margin pressure can have a negative impact on the entire process. Companies are harnessing the power of data for all aspects of the value chain. Data with purpose – advanced analytics, predictive analytics and artificial intelligence – is key to meeting these opportunities in a proactive manner.   

Equally important in a highly connected world where information is instantaneous, is that NOT meeting the customer's expectations could have an immediate, and disastrous, effect.  Creating trust and transparency along the entire chain can no longer be buzzwords.

Today's winners have found a way to develop and integrate innovative, collaborative, processes and analytics (a value chain approach) that are improving speed and margin, without sacrificing quality, to meet the trust and transparency needs of the consumer.  

Mike Flanagan, CEO of apparel industry consultancy Clothesource:
The industry's biggest problem is a crisis among the Western clothing retailers on whom hundreds of thousands of suppliers worldwide depend – as well as tens of millions of textile and garment workers in developing countries.

There's a belief that this is about poor sales. And it's intertwined with beliefs that online retailing is more efficient than physical; that clothes retailing is bound to move online; and that retailers who don't understand this will price themselves out of business – if they've not already alienated all the millennials who are their natural customers.

My Emperors' Clothes survey exposed all this months ago. Clothing retailers have their problems: but they're mostly about costs, not sales. They're targeting the young, when the middle-aged are clothing's big spenders. They're concerned with fashion, when their  customers want style. They're inadequately focused on consumer needs; absurdly deferential to the fads of outside consultants; spendthrift in IT, new branches and, above all, in what they pay their shareholders and senior management. And with no doubt remaining that selling clothes online reduces profits, it is now only a matter of time before the online retail bubble bursts.

But there's also a lengthening list of other misguided beliefs about our industry:
1: "In 2018, British retail saw its worst November in living memory." In fact, November 2018 saw higher UK retail sales than any November ever – and year-on-year growth was the fourth highest in the previous 30 years.

2: "Our industry has a spectacularly catastrophic impact on the world's pollution problems." The apparel and textile industry is just not big enough to do anything like the amount of damage its detractors claim: summarised in the phrase "the world's second biggest polluter." Yet, as the New York Times finally admitted in late December, the allegation is almost foundless. Yes, there's a lot it is doing wrong – but our industry can't solve the problems alone.

3: "Workers are being ruthlessly exploited." Scarcely a day goes by without complaints of awful wages in developing countries – and even in the onshore garment industry. But the ILO's 2018/19 Global Wage Report showed that between 2008 and 2017, real wages in Bangladesh (actual average wages deflated by CPI) increased 34%. That means workers in factories making garments for export. The ILO report shows almost all emerging economies saw substantial real wages growth over those ten years. It's likely garment wages did too. Claims that "minimum wages have grown by only x%" are not the same as cash wages not growing.   

4: "Innovation needs taxpayer subsidy to survive." By the end of 2018, governments had begun to attack the lavish exemptions from laws and taxes they had given internet retailers: the US Congress agreed to impose sales tax on out-of-State retail, while the UK began to show signs of similar sense on business rates; Canada announced its intention to withdraw uneconomic postal subsidies to Chinese businesses selling direct into the Canadian market; Donald Trump signalled similar plans; and India began discussing curbs on internet retailing amid fears about below-cost selling by its minuscule online retail industry. On this issue – if on few others – the developed world may well start watching India for advice.

5: "Robotics will destroy jobs." Robotics have a limited future in garment making. Businesses like Esquel are making huge strides in automation, but they're still employing as many as years ago. Drones have almost no role delivering stuff to people's houses: they'll get regulated like cars and might have a future in getting blood to hospitals, but they'll never deliver a T-shirt.

6: "Shareholders will keep letting Big Tech hurl money away." Amazon's 2017 losses on European retail were greater than the 2017 losses that drove Sears into bankruptcy. Investors aren't about to lose patience with the likes of Amazon – they've lost it already: in the last three months of 2018 alone, the paper value of Amazon fell over 30%.

Against all this, there are huge opportunities. Clothing sales keep growing, our customers are getting better off as they live – and stay style-conscious – for longer. Their growing diversity in tastes, body shapes, age, aspirations and priorities offer clothing designers and retailers huge opportunities for making money ethically and sustainably.

urn:contentItem:5RDV-VM71-JBNW-32SC-00000-00Outlook: Clock Ticking on Immigration, Spending2018-01-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisOutlook: Clock Ticking on Immigration, SpendingDaniel Newhauser

The already fragile negotiations over immigration and government spending became even shakier after President Trump reportedly asked a bipartisan group of lawmakers why he should accept immigrants from shithole countries, sparking outrage and casting a cloud over this week s talks.

Although government funding is set to lapse on Jan. 19, Democrats have refused to sign off on a government-spending deal until Republicans agree to legislation granting legal status to immigrants in the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program. Negotiators had yet to strike a deal as of last Friday, and Trump s remarks cast further doubt on whether they will.

Absent a deal, House Republicans could try to pass a continuing resolution on the strength of their own votes, but there is no guarantee conservative members would agree to that strategy, as they did in December. Furthermore, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell would need at least a few Democrats to sign off on a CR to advance it in his chamber.

Here s what else is on tap:

DEFENSE AND FOREIGN POLICY

Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen is set to testify Tuesday before a Senate Judiciary Committee oversight hearing.

On Wednesday, the Senate Intelligence Committee will consider the nominations of Michael Atkinson to be inspector general of the intelligence community and Jason Klitenic to be general counsel for the Office of the Director of National Intelligence. The panel is scheduled to meet again Thursday for a closed briefing.

On the other side of the Capitol, the House Foreign Affairs subcommittees on Terrorism, Nonproliferation, and Trade and Asia and the Pacific will hold a joint hearing on North Korea's biological, chemical, and conventional weapons with outside experts.

Meanwhile, Navy Secretary Richard Spencer and Chief of Naval Operations John Richardson are slated to testify Thursday before the House Armed Services subcommittees on Readiness and Seapower and Projection Forces.

ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT

The Senate Environment and Public Works Committee will gather a group of federal officials Wednesday to game out a path forward on another water-infrastructure bill. Chairman John Barrasso has called for action this year on a new Water Resources Development Act, which lawmakers regularly use to update policy and spending authorizations on water navigation, flood protection, and related environment policy.

That effort appears to be moving in parallel with a broad infrastructure package. The White House is now floating a $200 billion plan, and Wednesday s hearing will be the third on infrastructure for the Senate environment committee since late December.

A disaster-relief bill still hangs in the balance as Senate appropriators try to map out a path forward. The chamber s Democrats have called for a resolution on disaster funding as part of broader negotiations on federal spending and budget legislation, which lawmakers must act on before spending authorization expires Jan. 19.

Meanwhile, the House Energy and Commerce Committee will hold a hearing Thursday on the Environmental Protection Agency s Superfund policies. No witnesses have been announced yet, and the Trump administration hasn t nominated anyone to fill the top slot for the EPA office that controls Superfund, a program designed to clean up the country s most polluted industrial sites. Republican committee leaders recently raised questions about how the agency developed a list released in early December that identifies 21 sites as top priorities.

That committee will also hold a hearing Friday on legislation to modernize the Puerto Rican electricity utility, a notoriously inefficient and outdated service, and another bill to speed up the regulatory process for liquefied-natural-gas exports. The Trump administration habitually calls for increased LNG sales abroad to boost the bottom lines of American energy companies.

HEALTH

House Republicans seem confident that a deal will be reached on Children s Health Insurance Program funding this week, with Energy and Commerce Chairman Greg Walden saying they are looking a six-year deal. Democrats, however, are pushing for more.

Meanwhile, committees on both sides of Congress will be taking on a slew of health policy topics. The House Rules Committee will consider a bill Tuesday that would require a health care practitioner who is present when a child is born alive following an abortion to exercise care and ensure that that the child is immediately admitted to a hospital. Practitioners who do not follow these requirements could be fined, face up to five years in prison, or both.

The House Ways and Means Oversight Subcommittee will hold a hearing Wednesday on the opioid crisis. Members will look at Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services efforts to use data to identify people in the Medicare Part D program who may abuse opioids, as well as what tools CMS has to prevent people from receiving unnecessary opioids.

The Energy and Commerce Committee Health Subcommittee will also mark up three health-related bills that would shield health care professionals from liability when they volunteer during a declared disaster, clarify how drug and device companies can share health care economic or scientific information and establish an over-the-counter monograph user fee program at the Food and Drug Administration.

On Wednesday, the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee will hold a hearing on the reauthorization of the Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness Act, which helps the country prepare for a range of public health threats.

The Senate Judiciary Crime and Terrorism Subcommittee will also have a hearing on the long-term-care needs of first responders injured in the line of duty.

TAXES

Tax writers are combing the recently passed overhaul bill for areas that may need fixing through upcoming legislation, but they don t expect tweaks to be attached to a bill to fund the federal government.

I wouldn t anticipate that, House Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady told reporters last Thursday. We re going to make sure any fine-tuning we do is well thought-out.

Ways and Means announced a subcommittee reshuffle last week, moving Rep. Peter Roskam to lead the Health Subcommittee and Rep. Lynn Jenkins to head the Oversight Subcommittee. Both of these positions will be key this year as Congress mulls another run at repealing the Affordable Care Act and tax writers gear up for a reorganization of the Internal Revenue Service, which would fall under Jenkins s jurisdiction. Rep. Vern Buchanan will chair the Tax Policy Subcommittee this year, just as the panel gets ready to work on technical corrections to the tax bill, a separate tax-extenders bill, and further tax-code changes.

The need for additional IRS resources to implement the overhaul bill remains an open issue as Congress grapples with funding legislation for fiscal 2018. IRS Taxpayer Advocate Nina Olson released her annual report last week, saying the agency would need nearly $500 million over the next two years to implement the tax-code changes.

Brady said last week that lawmakers are still open to the idea of additional funding and are vetting proposals, and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said at an economic forum Friday that he expects the IRS to hire a significant number of additional staff for the implementation push.

TECHNOLOGY

The Senate is scheduled to vote Tuesday on a House resolution, passed last week, that reauthorizes Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act without the privacy reforms sought by lawmakers on both sides of the aisle. The House bill sets no limits on the warrantless use of Americans intercepted electronic communications by law enforcement, which has been a key sticking point in the months-long debate on reauthorization.

Democratic Sen. Ron Wyden and Republican Sen. Rand Paul have both threatened to filibuster similar legislation, and several other senators including Republicans Mike Lee and Steve Daines and Democrat Patrick Leahy have expressed grave reservations about reauthorizing the surveillance program without reforms. The bill would need 60 votes to pass in the upper chamber should any senator choose to filibuster. The foreign electronic surveillance program which the intelligence community insists is vital to national security will expire on Jan. 19 absent another extension.

Expect more reaction from senators regarding last week s report that Russian-government hackers are seeking to compromise Senate network accounts. On Friday, GOP Sen. Ben Sasse called on Attorney General Jeff Sessions to update Congress on what steps the Department of Justice has taken to protect Congress and other federal networks from Russian cyberattacks.

The Senate Commerce Committee is having its first tech-focused week of the new year. On Wednesday, the committee will hear from representatives of Facebook, Google, and Twitter on their efforts to fight the spread of terrorist and extremist content on their platforms. The title of the hearing Is Big Tech Doing Enough? suggests Silicon Valley may be in for some tough questions.

On Thursday, the Commerce Committee will convene an executive session to consider the nomination of Brendan Carr, the newest Republican member of the Federal Communications Commission, to a new term. Republicans had hoped to nominate Carr to two consecutive terms last year, after he was tapped last summer to finish out the term of former FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler. But Sen. Bill Nelson, the ranking member on Commerce, scuttled that approach over concerns that Carr lacks independence from his former boss, FCC Chairman Ajit Pai.

The House Homeland Security Committee will meet Wednesday to discuss the Continuous Diagnostic and Mitigation cybersecurity system. Run by the Homeland Security Department, the CDM program is designed to constantly scan and fortify federal networks against cyberattack, but it s still in its early stages. Wednesday s hearing is set to bring together federal stakeholders with industry experts to examine barriers to rolling out the program across the federal government.

On Wednesday, the House Science, Space, and Technology Committee will hear from representatives of NASA, Boeing, and private-space firm SpaceX for an update on NASA commercial-crew systems development. The House Energy and Commerce Committee will hold a hearing Thursday on the manufacturing and innovation of Internet of Things devices.

WHITE HOUSE

Back in Washington after a long weekend in Florida, President Trump will spend only two days in town before hitting the road in an effort to save a Republican seat in the House. On Tuesday, he will meet with Kazakhstan President Nursultan Nazarbayev. On Wednesday, he will attend the ceremony when the Congressional Gold Medal is presented to former Senate Majority Leader and GOP presidential nominee Bob Dole, who is 94. Then, on Thursday, he will travel to a manufacturing plant outside Pittsburgh to campaign for Rick Saccone, the Republican hoping to fill the vacancy created when GOP Rep. Tim Murphy resigned amid scandal. The special election is March 13. On Friday, the president will host an event related to the 45th annual March for Life, protesting the Supreme Court s 1973 abortion decision. Then, he is back to his Florida golf resort.

urn:contentItem:5YCT-VVN1-DY4X-T010-00000-00Outlook: Congress faces surveillance-powers deadline2020-03-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisOutlook: Congress faces surveillance-powers deadlineZach C. Cohen, Casey Wooten, Brian Dabbs

Congress is facing a deadline to renew expiring surveillance authorities before they jet home for the St. Patrick's Day recess.

Three provisions of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act are set to lapse Saturday, the end of a   four-month reauthorization approved by Congress in November. Bipartisan, bicameral interest remains in reform amid high-profile cases of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court s approval of observation of U.S. citizens, but consensus on actual measures remains elusive.

Senate leadership has signaled that they want to reauthorize the expiring provisions for as long as three months to prevent them for lapsing as lawmakers continue to negotiate. Sen. Rand Paul, a longtime critic of the Patriot Act, has said he d oppose even a temporary extension.

It s kind of [a] game of chicken right now [between] those who want to use it as leverage to do Title I reform and those of us who want to make sure those authorities are still available in the interim, said Sen. John Cornyn, a McConnell ally on the Intelligence Committee. We re not gonna decide Title I FISA reform between now and March 15, so that s what we re trying to manage.

President Trump, Attorney General William Barr, and congressional Republicans met last week on the issue, and Paul tweeted that Trump said he doesn t want a clean reauthorization of FISA.

In the House, Speaker Nancy Pelosi said she hopes to pass a FISA extension this week. House Judiciary Chairman Jerrold Nadler, who wants substantial changes as well, told Fox News on Thursday that he would let the FISA statute expire if lawmakers couldn t reach a deal. The House Judiciary Committee postponed a markup of its reauthorization legislation in late February and hasn t set another date.

We re having our own negotiations within our own group, among the Democrats and vis-a-vis the Republicans, Pelosi said.

The Congressional Progressive Caucus, who have struck a rare point of agreement with the conservative Republican Freedom Caucus on the issue, have been in talks with leadership on the FISA bill.

It is our position that the House should pass a very strong, reformed reauthorization, Progressive Caucus cochair and Judiciary Committee member Pramila Jayapal told reporters Wednesday.

Jayapal says she continues to push for a definition of the derived from clause in the FISA statute, which would help individuals challenge the legality of surveillance done on them, and for requiring that certain surveillance be deleted after three years. The third issue is stronger protection for First Amendment-protected activity, Jayapal said.

The Senate will return Monday to vote to advance Sen. Lisa Murkowski s substitute amendment to her massive energy bill. Murkowski packaged 18 noncontroversial amendments onto the energy package before the Senate skipped town last week. But that won t go far in placating a restive Democratic caucus that is pulling out all the stops to boost the climate-change impact of the legislation.

Senators filed roughly 200 amendments on the legislation. A high-profile measure to tack incentives for energy-efficiency improvements to residential and commercial buildings is set for a vote. The outcome on that amendment is so far unclear, and many Republicans are rallying against it.

Democrats view the building-code measure as the biggest potential guarantee for greenhouse-gas-emission reductions in the energy package. Its inclusion, or lack thereof, may go a long way in determining Democratic support for the package as a whole. The National Association of Home Builders, a lobbying powerhouse, opposes the measure.

On top of that, Democrats and some Republicans, like Sen. John Kennedy, are pushing an amendment vote on legislation to mandate hydrofluorocarbon phasedowns in the refrigerants industry. Democrats are also pushing a suite of clean-energy tax cuts. The latter is a long shot. A tax-credit attachment to the package will surely generate a revenue-related blue-slip point of order from House members.

It s a busy week for Murkowski. On Tuesday, she ll hold a hearing to examine the 16 percent cut proposed for the Interior Department in the White House budget for fiscal 2021. Interior Secretary David Bernhardt will testify before the committee.

Kennedy will also convene the Senate Appropriations Financial Services and General Government Subcommittee on Tuesday to hear from three members of the Federal Communications Commission on their budget request.

The next day, Chairman Richard Shelby brings together the Defense Subcommittee to consider Navy and Marine Corps funding while Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith convenes the Legislative Branch panel to review the Government Accountability Office and Congressional Budget Office. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Ben Carson will also testify, and hearings on the Army Corps of Engineers and the Bureau of Reclamation within the Department of the Interior are also slated for Wednesday.

Finally, Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue will appear before Sen. John Hoeven s Agriculture Subcommittee on Thursday.

The Senate Committee on Rules and Administration is set to hold a contentious hearing on Tuesday as Sen. Roy Blunt attempts to advance James Trainor s nomination to sit on the Federal Election Commission. Sen. Amy Klobuchar, the panel s ranking member fresh off her campaign for president,   opposes Trainor s advancement   without the traditional Noah s Ark-style, simultaneous nomination of a Democrat to the bipartisan board charged with overseeing elections.

In the House, lawmakers will vote on the No Ban Act , which would limit the administration s ability to restrict immigration and terminate the president s executive actions banning travel from certain countries. Days into his administration, Trump issued an order denying certain visas to travelers from seven Muslim-majority countries. That was eventually pared down, but in January, Trump expanded the ban to include Myanmar, Eritrea, Kyrgyzstan, Sudan, Tanzania, and Nigeria, all countries with substantial Muslim populations.

It s not likely that Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell would take up the legislation.

The House will also take up another immigration-related bill. The Access to Counsel Act would guarantee the right to representation to undocumented immigrants during removal, exclusion, or deportation proceedeings. The current statutes only grant representation rights during removal proceedings. Sen. Kamala Harris has similar   legislation in the Senate, but it has not moved in the Judiciary Committee.

House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer said Sen. Tim Kaine s bill limiting Trump s military authority to attack Iran may come up for a vote this week as well. Kaine s resolution is set to get a hearing in the House Rules Committee Monday, meaning a vote is likely soon.

Here s what else is on tap this week:

DEFENSE AND FOREIGN POLICY

The Senate Armed Services Committee hopes to move three Trump nominees for Pentagon leadership Tuesday: Matthew Donovan, to be undersecretary of Defense for personnel and readiness; William Gillis, to be assistant secretary of Defense for sustainment; and Victor Mercado, to be assistant secretary of Defense for strategy, plans, and capabilities.

Marine Corps and Navy officials testify to the committee on Wednesday morning on ground-modernization efforts. The committee calls Pentagon officials to testify on personnel programs in the afternoon.

The House Armed Services Committee keeps up its breakneck pace next week, with eight hearings on the docket.

The committee calls U.S. Central Command Commander Gen. Kenneth McKenzie and Africa Command Commander Gen. Stephen Townsend to testify Tuesday on U.S. policy in the Middle East and Africa. Lawmakers have pushed back on rumors of a withdrawal from Africa, the first region under Defense Secretary Mark Esper s blank-slate review of military deployments around the world.

Anti-domestic violence and counseling officials testify Tuesday afternoon to the Military Personnel Subcommittee. Also that afternoon, acquisition officials testify to the Tactical Air and Land Forces Subcommittee on helicopter acquisition in the 2021 budget.

The committee hears testimony Wednesday on the United States sealift capacity. The Pentagon inspector general recently found that Transportation Command had inaccurately tracked sealift capacity, which could lead combatant commands to make assumptions about the initial availability of equipment and resupply of critical items during a crisis or major conflict.

U.S. Southern Command and Northern Command leadership testify to the full committee Wednesday morning on national security policy in North and South America. That afternoon, top research and engineering officials from the Army, Navy, and Air Force testify with Undersecretary of Defense for Research and Engineering Michael Griffin on the Pentagon s technology policy in 2021.

The committee focuses on missile defense in the 2021 budget on Thursday, with testimony from Missile Defense Agency and NORTHCOM leadership. The committee hears that morning from Navy and Marine Corps officials on readiness in 2021.

The House Foreign Affairs Committee calls the first hearing this week on Afghanistan policy since the U.S. and the Taliban signed a peace accord on Feb. 29, nominally setting the stage for full-blown peace talks in Kabul. Intra-Afghan negotiations are supposed to start on Tuesday, the same day that the committee calls former diplomats and off-Hill experts to testify on the negotiations.

That morning, House appropriators will examine Trump s 2021 budget request for the State Department.

On Wednesday, the Middle East and North Africa Subcommittee hears testimony on the humanitarian crisis in Idlib, Syria. The Europe Subcommittee focuses on the conflict in Ukraine that afternoon.

The same day, the House Appropriations Committee examines Trump s 2021 budget request for the State Department.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has one hearing scheduled for next week, on Bashar al-Assad s human rights abuses in Syria.

ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT

The energy package will consume the lion s share of attention in the energy-and-environment world this week. But energy experts will also scrutinize Interior and Energy Department testimony on the budget.

On top of Bernhardt s Senate testimony, the House is continuing to blitz on spending oversight. The Interior Secretary will appear before the House Appropriations Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies Subcommittee on Wednesday.

As usual with budget testimony, House Democrats are likely to veer into policy matters. Expect subcommittee Chair Betty McCollum to press Bernhardt on the status of approved mining leases in the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness, a vast network of waterways that cross the Minnesota border with Canada. McCollum, who represents a Minnesota district, is leading legislation to permanently ban development in the wilderness area.

The Energy and Water Development panel will receive budget testimony Wednesday on the Advanced Research Projects Agency Energy, a program that has been critical in boosting new energy technologies. The program s director, Lane Genatowski, will testify. The Trump administration has repeatedly proposed to nix the program.

But lawmakers on Capitol Hill prioritize ARPA E, and they ve boosted funding for it in recent years. The Murkowski energy package reauthorizes the program through 2025 with dramatically escalating funding authorization. The bill authorizes $750 million for ARPA E in fiscal 2025.

Meanwhile, the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee will hold a hearing Wednesday on Douglas Benevento to be deputy administrator at the Environmental Protection Agency. The hearing will also consider Nuclear Regulatory Commission nominations for David Wright and Christopher Hansen. Wright s term expires this year and Hansen will be a new addition to the commission.

HEALTH

Trump signed legislation providing $8.3 billion in supplemental funding to beef up the U.S. s response to the COVID-19 outbreak. But lawmakers are still concerned about the costs and practical impacts the disease can have on U.S. citizens as the disease spreads.

Public health threats like this outbreak have hidden and higher costs for those who are paid lower wages, who don t have affordable child care, who don t have health insurance, or who are experiencing homelessness, said Sen. Patty Murray, top Democrat on the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee. As we continue responding to this crisis I m going to stay focused on what all our families are actually experiencing and what they need to keep themselves and their communities safe.

The House Appropriations subcommittee with oversight of the Health and Human Services Department meets Tuesday on the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention budget for fiscal 2021. CDC Director Robert Redfield, a member of the Coronavirus Task Force, will be among the witnesses testifying.

The House Committee on Small Business also holds a hearing that morning looking at the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on small businesses, including supply-chain disruptions and the spread of misinformation.

In the afternoon, the House Homeland Security Committee s Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Recovery Subcommittee will look at community perspectives on coronavirus preparedness. Witnesses include health officials from the state health departments in New Jersey and Mississippi. The next morning, the full committee will meet on the federal response to the disease outbreak.

The House Oversight and Reform Committee s subcommittees on national security and economic and consumer policy will hold a hearing Tuesday afternoon on biodefense and the response to the outbreak. The full committee will have a hearing Wednesday morning on coronavirus preparedness and response, and in the afternoon, the Economic and Consumer Policy subcommittee will have a hearing on travel insurance for coronavirus-related cancellations.

Food and Drug Administration Commissioner Stephen Hahn will be on Capitol Hill on Wednesday to testify on the agency s fiscal 2021 budget. The hearing is in front of the appropriations subcommittee with oversight of the FDA s budget.

The House Education and Labor Committee s Workforce Protections Subcommittee will examine the Healthy Families Act from Rep. Rosa DeLauro on Wednesday. The legislation would require businesses with 15 or more employees to provide at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to a maximum of 56 hours in a year.

DeLauro and Murray recently introduced legislation building off of this proposal that would automatically provide 14 days of paid sick leave at the beginning of a public-health emergency, like the coronavirus outbreak.

On Thursday, the Senate Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship holds a hearing on how the coronavirus has impacted small businesses supply chains.

TAXES AND TRADE

COVID-19 is making its way into the tax world.

Trump pressed House Democrats last week to consider a one-year payroll-tax cut to ease the financial burden for individuals as fears of the virus roil the stock market. Hoyer shot down the idea to reporters during his pen-and-pad briefing last week, saying he didn t think that tax cuts are the answer to every problem.

On the Senate side, Finance Committee Republicans remain open to the idea but say the issue isn t yet urgent.

At this point, the coronavirus has not had a broad impact on the U.S. economy and its effects have been limited, a Senate Finance Committee aide told National Journal on Friday. However, Chairman Grassley and the Senate Finance Committee stand ready to consider appropriate tax-relief responses if that becomes necessary and the extent of the problem can be determined.

Then on Friday, The Washington Post reported that the White House is considering deferring taxes for the travel and tourism industries, something that Trump could accomplish administratively.

Both sides have left the door open to stimulus of some sort but there appears to be little agreement on how to go about it in the event the virus continues to be a drag on the economy.

On the agency side, the IRS s Taxpayer Advocate Service is working with IRS leaders to craft a plan in case employees are affected by the coronavirus, Bloomberg Tax reported . It s the middle of tax-filing season, and a multitude of the agency s 75,000 employees calling in sick or avoiding the office could delay processing. Tony Reardon, president of the National Treasury Employees Union, told Bloomberg that he expected a briefing on the issue in the coming days.

There are no tax- or trade-related hearings scheduled in the Ways and Means Committee or Senate Finance Committee this week.

TECHNOLOGY

The fight over big tech s legal shield ratchets up another notch on Wednesday. Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham will hold a hearing on his new, bipartisan Earn It Act, which forces tech companies to forgo the liability protections afforded to them under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act if they fail to take additional steps to prevent child exploitation on their platforms. The bill would convene a commission, headed by the attorney general, tasked with determining whether platforms should continue to receive such protections.

Tech companies and civil-liberties groups have already lined up against the legislation, and Graham said last week that tech trade groups would be among those testifying at Wednesday s hearing.

The Senate Judiciary Committee will also put pressure on tech platforms at a Tuesday hearing of the Subcommittee on Antitrust, Competition Policy and Consumer Rights. Lawmakers plan to discuss how the largest platforms particularly Google and Amazon allegedly favor certain products over others in their search results.

And on Tuesday afternoon, the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Intellectual Property will meet to discuss how other countries are handling digital piracy. The hearing is the second in a series planned by subcommittee Chairman Thom Tillis, who hopes to rewrite the Digital Millennium Copyright Act in a way that could see tech platforms lose additional liability protections, this time relating to infringing works posted on their platforms.

A long-awaited report from the Cyberspace Solarium Commission arrives Wednesday, when lawmakers and commissioners convene to unveil the results of a seven-month effort to establish a long-term cybersecurity strategy for the United States. The effort was modeled off of President Eisenhower s 1953 Project Solarium, which sought a new way to combat the Soviet nuclear threat. That project guided U.S. policy until the end of the Cold War, and commissioners hope Wednesday s report will have a similar impact on U.S. cybersecurity policy.

The Senate Commerce Committee will mark up several high-profile tech bills Wednesday. The Access Broadband Act, passed last year by the House, would streamline federal-assistance programs to extend high-speed internet to rural communities. The Industries of the Future Act would push the administration to develop a research plan and increase research investments in technologies such as artificial intelligence, quantum computing and next-generation wireless networks. And the US SAFEWEB Act would reauthorize a law giving the Federal Trade Commission additional powers to crack down on online scams.

It s appropriations season on Capitol Hill, and tech is high on this week s agenda. The Senate Appropriations Committee meets Tuesday to examine the proposed budget of the Federal Communications Commission, followed the next day by the House committee. The House Homeland Security Committee meets Wednesday with administration officials to discuss the White House s budget proposal for both the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency and the Homeland Security Department s Science and Technology Directorate.

The Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee will hold a markup Wednesday, where lawmakers will consider two cybersecurity bills as well as drone-safety legislation.

WHITE HOUSE

Even while managing the coronavirus situation, Trump has lots of politics on his schedule for this week as well as a remarkable snub of a key political constituency. On Monday, he will meet with supporters and raise political funds for Republicans in Longwood, Florida, north of Orlando. On Tuesday, he will honor another supporter, giving the Presidential Medal of Freedom to retired Gen. Jack Keane, a conservative analyst on Fox News.

On Thursday, he will be the first president to snub the annual bipartisan St. Patrick s lunch on Capitol Hill, because it is hosted by Pelosi, whom he regularly attacks. Since the lunch began in 1987 to honor the visiting Irish prime minister, presidents have either attended or sent their vice president in recognition of the political clout of 34 million Irish-Americans. Instead, Trump will meet with Taoiseach Leo Varadkar alone at the White House as part of his official celebration of St. Patrick s Day. On Friday, he will again leave the White House for another Republican event, the annual meeting of the Republican Jewish Coalition in Las Vegas.

urn:contentItem:60V4-BM41-JBNW-301D-00000-00Outlook: Congress plods toward a CR, election-season recess2020-09-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisOutlook: Congress plods toward a CR, election-season recessCasey Wooten, Zach C. Cohen

The House returns Monday with 12 voting days left this month, amid gridlock on COVID aid and members itching to get out on the campaign trail.

Last week, Senate Democrats blocked Majority Leader Mitch McConnell s skinny aid package, opting to hold fast on the $3.4 trillion HEROES Act passed by the House in May.

The short-term prospect for a COVID aid bill doesn t look good.

Well, looking to the House, and for that matter, our colleagues across the aisle, it s a sort of dead-end street, and very unfortunate, but it is what it is, Republican Sen. Pat Roberts told reporters Thursday after the failed cloture vote.

Congress, however, will likely avoid a government shutdown by passing a continuing resolution by the end of the month. How long the measure will last remains under negotiation between House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin.

We're down that path, Pelosi told reporters Thursday. We are now looking at anomalies and the rest, and we'll figure out the timing when we do.

The question is whether to draft a CR to run until December or into next year. McConnell supports a CR that lasts until December. For Democrats, a February deadline could mean Congress would be working with a Joe Biden administration and perhaps Sen. Chuck Schumer as majority leader on the spending package.

Both sides want a CR clear of extraneous items, but that doesn t rule out so-called anomalies, narrow changes to funding for certain agencies or programs. The CR won t include provisions meant for any coronavirus aid package, Pelosi told reporters last week, saying those negotiations are separate from this.

But ultimately, the parties may disagree on what constitutes a clean CR.

What we ve got to do as appropriators is define clean, Senate Appropriations Chairman Richard Shelby told reporters last week.

On the House docket this week is a series of education and civil rights-related bills. The House will take up a resolution from Rep. Grace Meng condemning anti-Asian sentiment caused by coronavirus. The House is also set to vote on Rep. Bobby Scott s Equity and Inclusion Enforcement Act , which would restore a private right of action for disparate-impact claims under the Civil Rights Act, and Rep. Marcia Fudge s Strength in Diversity Act , which would direct the Education Department to award grants to eliminate racial or socioeconomic isolation in publicly funded early-childhood programs.

The House is also scheduled to vote on Judiciary Chairman Jerrold Nadler s Pregnant Workers Fairness Act , which would prohibit employment practices that fail to make reasonable accommodations for job applicants or employees who are pregnant.

The Senate this week will likely confirm eight district-court nominees from California and Illinois, starting Monday afternoon with a procedural vote to advance attorney Mark Scarsi s nomination to be a district judge for the Los Angeles-anchored Central District of California.

Senators will also likely take up the nominations of Judge Stanley Blumenfeld and attorney John Holcomb for the Central District and federal prosecutor Todd Robinson for the San Diego-based Southern District. The four Illinois judicial nominees scheduled for confirmation are Judges David Dugan, Stephen McGlynn, Iain Johnston, and Franklin Valderrama.

Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee Chairman Ron Johnson plans to have the panel vote Wednesday to authorize additional subpoenas related to the FBI s 2016 counterintelligence investigation of the Donald Trump campaign and Burisma Holdings, a Ukrainian natural-gas company on whose board Joe Biden s son Hunter Biden once sat.

According to a private addendum to the agenda for the meeting obtained by National Journal, senators will be voting whether to depose nearly three dozen people, most of whom are Obama-era intelligence, diplomatic, and law enforcement officials who worked at the White House, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, and the Justice, State, and Treasury Departments.

Among those targeted is former Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew; former Deputy Treasury Secretary Sarah Raskin, the wife of Democratic Rep. Jamie Raskin; and Kevin Clinesmith, a former FBI lawyer who pleaded guilty last month as part of U.S. Attorney John Durham s review of the agency s counterintelligence investigation into Trump s 2016 campaign.

The Treasury Department last week sanctioned four Russia-linked individuals for attempting to interfere in the American election, specifically targeting Ukrainian lawmaker Andrii Derkach for his effort to compel corruption investigations based on unsubstantiated narratives. Democrats have repeatedly accused Republican senators of amplifying Russian disinformation. Johnson has denied that Derkach is a source in his probe of the Obama administration.

HSGAC will also consider whether to advance four nominees who testified before the committee last week , including Office of Personnel Management director nominee John Gibbs and three potential members of the Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board: John Barger of the Postal Service Board of Governors, former Bush administration official Christopher Burnham, and Frank Dunlevy.

The Senate Commerce Committee will also meet to advance five transportation nominees on Wednesday. Among those on the docket are Eric Soskin , Trump s pick to be the new inspector general of the Transportation Department, and former Rep. Todd Rokita to lead the Amtrak Board of Directors.

Both chambers on Wednesday plan to examine federal housing assistance during the coronavirus pandemic following the extension of the Federal Housing Administration s eviction moratorium late last month. The Senate Budget Committee will meet to oversee federal housing-assistance programs, while the House Financial Services Committee will hold a hearing on the response of federal housing giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to the crisis. The Financial Services Committee s other hearing on Thursday focuses on insider trading and stock-option grants.

The Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee will have two hearings this week on higher education. That panel on Tuesday will consider the ramifications of paying college athletes and on Thursday will hold a hearing on reforms to the federal student-aid application process.

Here s what else is on tap this week:

DEFENSE AND FOREIGN POLICY

Monday evening, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee holds a classified hearing on nuclear threats with officials from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, including two with expertise on Russia and China.

The Trump administration signaled last month that it would consider renewing the New START nuclear-arms-control treaty with Russia, after insisting for months that China must join talks. China has refused; Democrats and arms-control experts have urged President Trump to extend the treaty, which expires in February.

The House Foreign Affairs Western Hemisphere Subcommittee convenes virtually on Tuesday to hear testimony on Latin America and the Caribbean from off-Hill experts. That afternoon, the House Armed Services Readiness Subcommittee has called Pentagon officials to testify on the military s use of potentially toxic PFAS chemicals in firefighting foam.

Each of the four defense and foreign policy committees holds a hearing on Thursday.

The House Foreign Affairs Committee calls three State Department officials to testify on the firing of Inspector General Steven Linick, who spoke in June with House lawmakers investigating his removal. Linick said Undersecretary of State for Management Brian Bulatao tried to bully him; Bulatao will testify. State Department acting legal adviser Marik String and Assistant Secretary of State for political-military affairs R. Clarke Cooper will also testify, presumably on their involvement in the decision to bypass Congress and expedite weapons sales to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, a move Linick had been investigating.

The Inspector General found that the State Department did not fully assess the civilian-casualty risks of selling precision-guided missiles, which the two Gulf countries have used in neighboring Yemen.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who encouraged Trump to fire Linick, provided written answers about the probe. He traveled to Doha over the weekend for the start of intra-Afghan peace talks. Kabul and the Taliban have never negotiated face-to-face before, and the talks may enter a holding pattern as participants await the results of the U.S. presidential election.

The House Armed Services Emerging Threats Subcommittee has called members of the congressionally created National Security Commission on Artificial Intelligence to testify on the military s investments in AI technologies. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will consider U.S. diplomatic policy toward China, with testimony from State Department officials. And the Senate Armed Services Committee will hear from Lisa Gordon-Hagerty of the National Nuclear Security Administration about the agency s budget, alongside acquisition chief Ellen Lord and Adm. Charles Richard, commander of Strategic Command.

Defense hawks added language to the Senate s 2021 defense-policy bill that would let the military edit the NNSA s budget request before it s submitted to the White House for approval. The NNSA is housed within the Energy Department. House lawmakers have introduced a competing proposal, but the two chambers aren t expected to resolve their differences on the legislation before the presidential election.

ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT

A deal over a family of greenhouse gases called hydrofluorocarbons is paving the way for a resurrection of a sprawling Senate energy package that touches on everything from building efficiency codes to carbon capture and electrical-grid cybersecurity.

Senate Environment and Public Works Chairman John Barrasso and ranking member Tom Carper struck a compromise last week to phase down the use of those gases over a 15-year period in line with a United Nations accord called the Kigali Amendment. HFCs are common in refrigeration, air conditioning, and ventilation products, and major industry associations support regulation.

A spat between Barrasso and Carper over HFC regulation derailed action on the energy bill in March after Democrats banded against the legislation on the Senate floor.

Now, Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee Chair Lisa Murkowski, the lead sponsor of the energy package, is aiming to use the coming weeks to firm up support.

I m working with colleagues on both sides of the aisle to bring our bill back to the floor as soon as possible, but also recognize that given the calendar, that will require cooperation and good faith from members and stakeholders alike, Murkowski said in a statement to National Journal.

Senate passage could put pressure on House lawmakers to pass an energy package that has been steadily taking shape over the past year.

Meanwhile, the ENR Public Lands Subcommittee will hold a hearing Wednesday on a laundry list of public-lands bills, including a bipartisan measure to facilitate more firefighting-related forest management. Sens. Dianne Feinstein and Steve Daines are pushing legislation designed to expedite management projects. Environmental groups are lining up against it.

Record-breaking wildfires are scorching millions of acres on the West Coast.

ENR will also hold a hearing Wednesday on the nominations of Allison Clements and Mark Christie to be new members of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. Democrats have fought for months to secure the Clements nomination.

On the House side of the Capitol, an Energy and Commerce Committee panel will hold a hearing on the potential role of clean-energy investment in a pandemic recovery. A House infrastructure bill passed in July extends renewable-energy tax credits and ponies up billions to improve the electricity grid. The U.S. trails European counterparts in clean-energy stimulus amid the pandemic.

HEALTH

A Republican-backed coronavirus measure failed to advance in the Senate last week, and lawmakers remain at an impasse over a next COVID-19 package, even though housing protections and beefed-up unemployment benefits have ended.

House lawmakers are slated to vote on Rep. Meng's resolution condemning anti-Asian sentiment, a growing problem during the COVID-19 pandemic. The national coalition Stop AAPI Hate, which focuses on anti-Asian American discrimination during the pandemic, said in August that it received reports of 2,500 incidents of discrimination across the U.S. from March 19 to Aug. 5.

The House Veterans Affairs Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee will also have a hearing Wednesday on modernizing the Veterans Affairs Department supply chains and lessons learned during the pandemic.

The Senate Appropriations subcommittee with oversight of Health and Human Services Department funding will hold a hearing on the department s response to the pandemic. HHS Assistant Secretary for Health Brett Giroir, Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response Robert Kadlec, and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Director Robert Redfield will be testifying.

TAXES AND TRADE

It s unclear when the House will take up a pair of bills from Rep. John Larson meant to roll back the administration s payroll-tax-deferment program, but the House s chief administrator, Philip Kiko, said in a letter to staff Friday that the chamber itself won t defer payroll taxes.

Still, some members may enact the deferment for groups like campaign staff. House Ways and Means Committee ranking member Kevin Brady, a big booster of the White House deferral program that began Sept. 1, told reporters last week that his campaign administration will defer payroll taxes.

Other Republican campaigns are likely to follow suit.

Brady also mentioned another looming tax issue: tax extenders, the set of temporary tax provisions Congress must perennially renew. There hasn t been much talk about the block of extenders set to expire at the end of this year, but Brady said he expects negotiations to begin this week.

As for finding a legislative vehicle on which to attach extenders, the typical target is a government-funding bill, and one happens to be due at the end of this month, with perhaps another due at the end of the year.

Ways and Means is set to hold a hearing Thursday on enforcing the ban on imports produced by forced labor in the Xinjiang province of China.

The Senate Finance Committee hasn t announced any hearings this week.

TECHNOLOGY

The Senate Commerce Committee will mark up a slew of bills on Tuesday, and several tech-policy proposals are on tap. Senators will vote on bills including the Government Spectrum Valuation Act, the Rural Connectivity Advancement Program Act, and the Ensuring Network Security Act.

But the markup is perhaps more noteworthy for what s not on the agenda. Earlier this summer, former Commerce Chairman John Thune and committee member Brian Schatz introduced the PACT Act, an attempt to moderately reform Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. Big tech s primary legal shield is also targeted, albeit more aggressively, in the Online Freedom and Viewpoint Diversity Act introduced last week by Commerce Chairman Roger Wicker. The committee is not marking up either piece of legislation on Tuesday, however, which almost certainly kicks the fight over Section 230 to a new Congress in 2021.

With speculation swirling around the Justice Department s reported plan to bring an antitrust case against Google ahead of November s election, the Senate Judiciary Committee looks determined to air its own views on the issue. Lawmakers from the Antitrust Subcommittee will meet Tuesday with top Google executive Donald Harrison for a hearing on whether the tech company is harming competition through its search algorithms. Given the hearing s title Stacking the Tech: Has Google harmed competition in online advertising? it s safe to assume Harrison is in for a grilling.

Federal Communications Commission Chairman Ajit Pai may be in for his own grilling on Thursday. The House Energy and Commerce Communications and Technology Subcommittee will meet with FCC commissioners Thursday for a hearing entitled Trump FCC: Four Years of Lost Opportunities. In addition to questions about the commission's efforts to close the digital divide, lawmakers are likely to press commissioners on the ongoing inquiry into a White House petition asking the commission to reinterpret Section 230. The fate of Republican commissioner Michael O Rielly who had his renomination to the FCC abruptly pulled by the White House after he mildly criticized its Section 230 petition is also a likely topic of discussion.

The FCC is also busy elsewhere this week. On Monday, the commission will hold a day-long workshop on the development of Open Radio Access Networks, 5G technology widely touted as an economic alternative to the cheap hardware offered by Huawei, China s telecom giant and a purported national security threat. Washington has spent years seeking to convince allies to look beyond Huawei for their 5G needs, and more than one policymaker is pinning the success of that effort on the rapid development and deployment of alternate options like O-RAN.

The Senate Judiciary Intellectual Property Subcommittee meets Wednesday for a hearing on potential reforms to Section 1201 of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act, which prohibits individuals from trying to undermine technology deployed to prevent copyright violations.

President Trump's deadline for Chinese tech company ByteDance to sell TikTok the video app popular with American teens arrives on Tuesday, but a sale looks farther away than ever. On Friday, Reuters reported that the Chinese government would rather see TikTok shut down than have its ownership pass to an American firm. That report follows new export controls enacted by the Chinese government late last month, which many saw as an attempt to ensure Beijing could block a TikTok sale if it decided to do so.

Companies as diverse as Microsoft, Walmart, and Oracle have all expressed an interest in purchasing TikTok after the president signed an executive order seeking to shut down the app over national security concerns.

WHITE HOUSE

President Trump this week will celebrate a foreign policy accomplishment at the White House in between heavy campaigning in key battleground states. He starts the week on Monday with a visit to McClellan Park in Sacramento County, California to be briefed on the damage done by raging wildfires, followed by a stop in Arizona to conclude a three-day campaign swing. In Phoenix, he will attend a Latinos for Trump event before returning to Washington. On Tuesday, accompanied by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and a senior official from the United Arab Emirates, he will preside at the formal signing of the previously announced normalization agreement between the two countries. On Wednesday, he will participate in a phone call with Jewish leaders in advance of Rosh Hashanah, which begins Friday evening. In the evening, he will speak at a fundraising dinner for the National Republican Congressional Committee. On Thursday, he will attend a credentialing ceremony for newly appointed ambassadors to Washington. On Friday, he is back on the campaign trail, with rallies in Bemidji, Minnesota, and Mosinee, Wisconsin.
