urn:contentItem:5X2G-YT51-JBNW-300Y-00000-00Outlook: Congress Punts on Funding as Border Complicates Appropriations Process2019-09-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisOutlook: Congress Punts on Funding as Border Complicates Appropriations ProcessZach C. Cohen, Casey Wooten

Congress again needs to buy time to reach a deal to fund the government, but while the stopgap measure is likely to pass, the broader appropriations process has been rocky. The House will move first this week to pass stopgap-spending legislation to avert a Oct. 1 shutdown. The chamber will take up a clean continuing resolution to fund the government until late November. The measure is likely to pass without additional riders such as gun-control provisions or language preventing the president from transferring military construction funds to build a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border.

You probably wont have that in any CR, but youll probably have some other vehicle for that to be expressed, and we did have that conversation, Progressive Caucus cochair Mark Pocan said after exiting a meeting with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday. House movement on a short-term spending plan comes as the appropriations process in the Senate has run off the rails. The Senate appropriations subcommittees on Tuesday will attempt to markup three funding bills covering the White House, the federal judiciary, the District of Columbia, the Treasury, Transportation, and Housing and Urban Development Departments, and the Food and Drug Administration before the full panel takes them up Thursday. Senate Appropriations on Thursday advanced two bills funding the Defense and Energy Departments. Defense spending passed on a party-line vote in light of Republicans defeat of Democrats proposal to limit the Pentagons ability to divert funding to physical barriers on the southern border. Appropriators this week filed legislation forcing another vote this month to terminate the emergency declaration authorizing the transfers between military construction projects. Chairman Richard Shelby had planned to mark up two other bills, but disputes over funding for nongovernmental abortion services and topline funding for domestic priorities, including the Homeland Security Department, postponed their consideration. Appropriators nonetheless expressed cautious optimism that some funding bills could reach the floor as Congress creeps toward an Oct. 1 deadline to fund the government. I hope we wont get so bogged down here that we dont achieve what we, really on a bipartisan agreement, wanted to achieve, which was to avoid a CR, avoid a government shutdown, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell told the panel. The House will also take up legislation to ban forced arbitration this week. With 222 cosponsors, the bill is likely to pass. Sen. Richard Blumenthal has companion legislation in the Senate, but it has not advanced. Additional immigration and election security bills as well as floor votes on the three gun control bills the Judiciary Committee approved last week are expected to come during this work period as well, House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer told reporters Wednesday. Meanwhile, the Senate this week will spend floor time on confirming more executive-branch nominees. McConnell on Thursday filed cloture on three of Trumps State Department picks, including John Rakolta and Kenneth Howerys nominations for ambassadorial posts in the United Arab Emirates and Sweden as well as Robert Destros bid to be an assistant secretary. Also on the Senates docket are Brent McIntosh and Brian Callanans nominations to work at the Treasury Department as undersecretary and general counsel, respectively. The Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee on Thursday will also consider attorney Eugene Scalia, President Trumps nominee to run the Labor Department. The son of late Justice Antonin Scalia served in various roles at the Labor, Justice, and Education Department. Heres what else is on tap this week: DEFENSE AND FOREIGN POLICY The House Foreign Affairs Committee has subpoenaed President Trumps point man for Afghanistan peace negotiations, Zalmay Khalilizad, to appear at a hearing Thursday. The subpoena is the first the committee has issued this Congress, and comes after requests for his public testimonyin February, April and early Septemberwere unsuccessful, according to a committee press release. The subpoena was issued after President Trump abruptly canceled a secret meeting with the Taliban at Camp David, meant to finalize a peace framework that would have reportedly traded a withdrawal of U.S. troops for certain security guarantees from the Taliban. Trump called the talks "dead" last week. The committee has four other hearings lined up for Wednesday. In the morning, climate activist Greta Thunberg testifies to the committee on climate change, and David Stilwell, assistant Secretary of State for the Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, testifies on U.S. policy in the Asia-Pacific region. Later that afternoon, the committee calls outside experts to testify on the threat of domestic white nationalist terrorism. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has a similarly busy schedule, with two policy hearings, a nominations hearing, and a business hearing scheduled for this week. The committee calls Stilwell to testify Wednesday on Hong Kong and U.S. policy in the Indo-Pacific region. Senators are pressuring leadership to take up legislation in the next few weeks supporting protestors in Hong Kong. Later in the afternoon, Sen. Marco Rubio presides over the first Western Hemisphere Subcommittee hearing, set to focus on U.S.Colombia relations. At the business hearing Wednesday, the committee takes up ambassadorial nominations for Serbia, Latvia, multiple Pacific island nations, Bulgaria, Romania, the Bahamas, and the U.S. position at the Office of the United Nations and Other International Organizations in Geneva. Also on Wednesday, the committee considers Marshall Billingslea for undersecretary of State for Democracy and Human Rights, and Darrell Issa for the director of the International Development Finance Corporation, along with posts at the Broadcasting Board of Governors and the International Development Finance Corporation. The Senate Armed Services Committee calls outside experts to testify Tuesday on Southeastern Europe. The committee continues to negotiate with the House Armed Services Committee over the defense policy bill. ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT The battle between fossil-fuel allies and representatives of ethanol-producing corn country is likely to return to the spotlight this week. President Trump is approaching a self-imposed deadline Monday to unveil a Renewable Fuel Standard reform package amid an ongoing outcry from agricultural communities over Environmental Protection Agency blending exemptions for oil refiners. The RFS that mandates 15 billion gallons of ethanol are blended into U.S. gasoline annually. But the Trump administration has dramatically increased the number of exemptions doled out to refiners, who say they oppose the standard over logistical and financial burden. Ethanol supports say the exemptions slash 1 billion gallons of required blending. Last week, Trump met with key stakeholders in the debate, including the CEOs of refiners Valero Energy and Marathon Petroleum, as well as Sen. Chuck Grassley and other influential corn-state senators. Details of the potential package are murky. Meanwhile, EPA Administrator Andrew Wheeler is set to testify before the House Science, Space and Technology Committee on Thursday. Wheeler may field questions on ethanol blending, but the hearing is focused on the EPAs general treatment of science and technology. The agency has come under repeated fire from Democrats and environmental groups over climate-related and public-health regulations. On Wednesday, a House Transportation and Infrastructure subcommittee will convene a hearing on the Trump administrations priorities under the Clean Water Act. The EPA, along with the Army Corps of Engineers, finalized a rule last week to repeal the Obama-era Clean Water Rule, which expanded federal authority to regulate bodies of water. Also on Wednesday, the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Environment and Climate Change will hold a hearing on the path to a net-zero carbon economy, while a House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee and the climate select committee holds a hearing on global solutions to climate change. On the other side of the Capitol, the Energy and Natural Resources Committee on Tuesday will look into legislation to boost U.S. production of critical minerals, many of which are used in clean energy products. Sen. Lisa Murkowski, chairman of the committee, and Sen. Joe Manchin, the top Democrat, sponsor the American Mineral Security Act, legislation to assess reserves and expedite mine permitting. HEALTH House lawmakers will continue their scrutiny of how the U.S. government is treating unaccompanied immigrant children. The House Appropriations Labor and Health and Human Services Subcommittee is holding a hearing Wednesday on the mental health needs of children in the Health and Human Services Department's custody. There will be witnesses from the HHS Office of Refugee Resettlement and the Office of Inspector General. On Thursday, the House Energy and Commerce Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee will also hold a hearing on the treatment of unaccompanied children, including testimony from Customs and Border Protection and the HHS Office of Inspector General and Office of Refugee Resettlement. Both hearings come after the OIG reported earlier this month that facilities housing unaccompanied minors had challenges in addressing the mental health needs of children who had experienced trauma, such as fleeing violence or being separated from their parents. National Journal has also reported on the issues of mental health care in shelters housing immigrant children. Members of the House Veterans Affairs Committee on Wednesday will examine how hiring and retention challenges at the Veterans Affairs Department impact patient care. Lawmakers will look at how pay, cost of living, and administrative barriers impact the VAs hiring abilities. The House Energy and Commerce Consumer Protection and Commerce Subcommittee on Thursday will hold a hearing regarding pharmaceutical product hopping, when a company reformulates or modifies a drug in order to avoid generic competition. According to the Federal Trade Commission, a company can withdraw its original product, forcing patients to use the reformulated version, and enabling the company to keep its market exclusivity. TAXES AND TRADE U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer delivered his responses to House Democrats concerns on the new North American trade agreement on Wednesday, setting the stage for crucial meetings this week. The U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement working group of Democratic lawmakerswho are are focused on the deal's provisions on labor, the environment, prescription drugs, and the enforcement mechanismwill gather to assess the reply, and then will meet with Lighthizer. The Trump administration is pushing to pass the trade agreement this fall. On Thursday, House Ways and Means Oversight Subcommittee Chairman John Lewis will hold a hearing on how the tax code subsidizes hate. Witnesses have not been announced, but lawmakers will likely listen to testimony on white-supremacist organizations with tax-exempt status. TECHNOLOGY Federal antitrust enforcers are likely to get an earful from senators during a Tuesday oversight hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee. FTC Chairman Joseph Simons will join Makan Delrahim, the head of the Justice Departments Antitrust Division, for a meeting to examine enforcement of the antitrust laws. And lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have expressed concern that enforcementespecially when it comes to the technology industryhas been lacking. Wide-ranging antitrust probes recently announced by state attorneys general against Facebook and Google have convinced many senators that the FTC and DOJ are dragging their feet on competition issues related to big tech. Theyve suggested theyll use their oversight authorities to browbeat federal regulators into following the states leadand on Tuesday, theyll have that chance. Some lawmakers may go one step further and question whether federal agencies are up to the task of policing Facebook, Google, or other giant tech firms. Last week, Sen. Josh Hawley repeatedly told reporters hes worried that the structure of the FTC may not lend itself to pursuing strenuous antitrust actions targeting the tech industry. The industry is itself slated for its own Senate drubbing this week. On Wednesday, the Senate Commerce Committee will meet with representatives from Facebook, Google, and Twitter for a hearing on the companies efforts to remove violent and extremist content from their platforms. All three companies, but especially Facebook and Twitter, have come under serious scrutiny for their failure to crack down on terrorist and white-nationalist content, as well as content that promotes mass violence. The debate over the tech industrys response to violent content is part of a broader discussion surrounding Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, which grants broad legal liability protections to the tech platforms for content posted by their users. Elements of both the right and left are now seeking to dismantle some or all of those protections, in a bid to impose their own preferred content-moderation policies on the platforms. The House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology meets Wednesday for a hearing on developing NASA capabilities for deep-space exploration. On Thursday, the same committee meets for a hearing on how to better engage American students in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics fields. WHITE HOUSE Lots of politics, a little pomp, and a dash of foreign policy are on President Trumps schedule this week. On Monday, he presents the Presidential Medal of Freedom to yet another one of his sports heroes, former New York Yankee pitcher Mariano Rivera, before welcoming Bahrains Crown Prince Salman bin Hamad Al Khalifa to the White House. In the evening, its off to Albuquerque for a political rally. On Tuesday and Wednesday, hell be in California to raise political money in Palo Alto, Beverly Hills, Los Angeles, and San Diego. Back in Washington on Friday, he will throw a state dinner for Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison.

urn:contentItem:607P-KDM1-JBNW-30CV-00000-00Outlook: Congress shifts attention from policing to NDAA, infrastructure2020-06-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisOutlook: Congress shifts attention from policing to NDAA, infrastructureCasey Wooten, Zach C. Cohen

Policing reform is in a legislative quagmire and the country s biggest states are dealing with another spike in COVID-19 cases as the Senate likely won t take up another aid bill before late July.

Congress is struggling to manage the dual crises facing America amid the kind of partisan sniping typically reserved for things like government-spending fights. But there s no continuing resolution to put off the advance of a pandemic or to calm the uproar over the killing of unarmed Black people by police.

The House passed on Thursday its version of policing reform legislation. That bill won t advance in the Senate, which failed to pass its own version a day before when Democrats opposed a procedural vote. So far, there is little talk of lawmakers working out a deal this week ahead of a two-week Independence Day recess.

I d say it s on the backburner for a good while, because I don t think there d be any attempt to do anything else when you put a kind of quietus on the process, Republican Sen. Mike Braun said Thursday of the failed Senate effort.

Momentum on a bill is dissipating as we speak, Sen. Tim Scott, the Senate bill s sponsor, said Thursday. So far, Democrats are sticking to their legislation, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi calling the Senate effort toothless.

The Senate has to do better, Pelosi told reporters Friday. So it isn t about this whole thing of equivalence, why can t you work together, because they don t share their values on this subject. Not yet, but I hope that they will.

On Monday, the House will vote on legislation to expand the Affordable Care Act. The measure would expand ACA subsidies for health care premiums, increase federal Medicaid funding, and outlaw so-called junk health plans, among other changes.

The move is a tack to the center compared to calls for Medicare-for-all, but won t get much attention in the Republican Senate. Still the vote serves to contrast Democrats health care policy priorities from the administration ahead of the November election, and as cases from COVID-19 spike. The vote also comes as the White House asks the Supreme Court to strike down the ACA in its entirety as part of a case the court will hear this fall.

The House will likely vote on Monday on two bills the chamber debated after the final votes on Friday. Rep. Josh Gottheimer s Protecting Your Credit Score Act of 2019, H.R. 5332 , would revamp requirements for credit-reporting agencies.

The House will also vote Monday on a Congressional Review Act resolution meant to roll back a rule that would weaken a key anti-redlining law. The Senate isn t likely to advance that measure, however.

Later in the week, the House will vote on The Moving Forward Act, a $1.5 trillion infrastructure package. The rules committee is set on Monday to consider the bill, which would provide funds for updating roads and bridges, reducing traffic congestion, and a series of green initiatives. The president has suggested he s open to an infrastructure package, but hasn t provided details. Senate Republicans have balked at the price tag of the House Democrats legislation.

Senators this week will turn to the National Defense Authorization Act. The Senate voted 90-7 on Thursday to squash progressive Democrats filibuster and end debate on the motion to proceed the annual military bill, teeing up a Monday afternoon vote to take it up.

Senate Armed Services Chairman James Inhofe said last week that he hoped to pass the $741 billion package by Thursday. Senators filed 529 amendments before Friday s deadline. The House Armed Services Committee will   mark up that chamber s version on Wednesday.

Notwithstanding all our other differences, I hope and expect this body will be able to put partisanship aside and honor the bipartisan tradition that has defined this crucial bill for decades, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell in a floor speech on Thursday.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said Democrats will use the final week before a planned Independence Day recess to push for legislation related to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, which has killed more than 125,000 Americans. That will include calls to pass bills on housing and rental assistance, hazard pay for essential workers, and relief for small businesses, schools, and state and local governments.

Democrats are not going to wait until late July to bring some attention to COVID-related issues, Schumer said.

With circuit courts as of last week lacking any vacancies for the first time in at least four decades, the Senate Judiciary Committee will hold a hearing on Tuesday on the Judicial Conference s recommendation that Congress create more positions on the federal bench in order to address those jurisdictions caseload backlog.

Federal judges, including Chief Justice John Roberts, last year urged Congress to add nearly two dozen new judgeships for the president and Senate to fill. There is bipartisan support for some of the recommendations for new trial-court judges, but Democrats resisted Republicans push to grow by five seats the San Francisco-based 9th Circuit Court of Appeals, a frequent forum for challenges to Trump administration policy to which the president has named   a third of its bench.

In other nomination news, the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee scheduled to hear from Derek Kan, Trump s nominee to be deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget. The Budget Committee   last week interrogated Kan, currently OMB s executive associate director.

With colleges and universities debating how or whether to return in person this fall, the Senate Commerce Committee will examine the NCAA Board of Governors'   recommended modernization of rules of commercialization of student-athletes. The Commerce Committee has jurisdiction over Sen. Marco Rubio s   bill introduced this month that would require intercollegiate athletic associations to allow for compensation of student-athletes for use of their name, image, and likeness.

Here s what else is on tap this week:

DEFENSE AND FOREIGN POLICY

The House Armed Services Committee meets Wednesday for deliberation on the chairman s mark of the 2021 defense policy bill, the final and most arduous step before the legislation heads for broader debate on the House floor.

The legislation includes $1 billion in coronavirus-related spending, far more than the Senate legislation. The topline figure on the House legislation is $731.6 billion, below the $740.5 billion   authorized in the Senate.

The two bills contain many similarities, like boosted funding for the new Pacific Deterrence Initiative, and heightened focus on artificial intelligence. Ranking Republican Mac Thornberry has said he could support the bill as written, although Democrats are likely to add more contentious amendments during the markup.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee convenes remotely Tuesday to hear expert testimony on pandemic-response reforms. Lawmakers are considering legislation that would reorganize the federal bureaucracy and pump money into the State Department and U.S. Agency for International Development for pandemic response abroad, and heard from Trump administration officials last week. Democrats are wary of endorsing reforms that would undermine the World Health Organization following Trump s move to withdraw.

The House Foreign Affairs Committee calls Brian Bulatao, a top State Department official, to testify on the firing of inspector general Steven Linick Thursday. Linick said during testimony to the committee that he felt bullied at times by Bulatao, who attempted to convince him to drop an investigation of emergency arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.

According to a recent Foreign Policy story, the Trump administration is considering ending the decades-old practice of informally notifying arms sales to Congress.

The committee holds two other hearings, both about China. Members hear testimony Tuesday from experts on China s maritime ambitions, and Wednesday on the implications of China s national security law for Hong Kong. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo recently determined that Hong Kong is no longer sufficiently autonomous from mainland China to merit special privileges under U.S. law. The State Department announced sanctions against Chinese officials responsible for undermining Hong Kong s autonomy Friday.

Hong Kong will also feature in the upcoming floor debate in the Senate over the NDAA, where Sens. Pat Toomey and Chris Van Hollen intend to file legislation as an amendment to the bill that would impose secondary sanctions on Chinese banks. The legislation passed the Senate through voice vote last Thursday, and Senate Armed Services Committee chairman Inhofe has expressed support for the measure.

Inhofe s floor speech last week prefacing debate focused almost entirely on China.

Following a bombshell New York Times report that a Russian military intelligence unit offered Taliban-linked militants bounties for killing coalition forces in Afghanistan and that the president was briefed on it, and has not authorized a response   some   lawmakers are calling for hearings and a congressional investigation.

ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT

House Democrats are hoping to sign off this week on their biggest climate-related legislative achievement so far this Congress.

The infrastructure package, a $1.5 trillion measure dubbed the INVEST in America Act, extends tax credits for renewable industries like wind and solar energy, as the sector hemorrhages jobs and struggles to finance projects amid the coronavirus pandemic.

A range of provisions are also included to invest heavily in transportation sector electrification and encourage new construction with climate change-resistant materials. Republicans opposed many of those measures in committee.

On Tuesday morning, Pelosi and Rep. Kathy Castor, the chair of the House Select Committee on the Climate Crisis, will unveil the committee s long-awaited comprehensive climate policy report.

In the Senate, the Environment and Public Works Committee is holding a hearing Wednesday on infrastructure. Chairman John Barrasso is pledging to pass an infrastructure package this year, but he recently described the House package as a partisan highway bill on a road to nowhere.

Meanwhile, Senate lawmakers are aiming to tack high-profile energy provisions onto the 2020 defense authorization bill during a floor process this week that could consume days of amendment debate and votes.

Sen. Lisa Murkowski is pushing amendments on both the American Mineral Security Act , a bill that s designed to boost domestic production of minerals used in clean energy and other advanced technologies, and the   Nuclear Energy Leadership Act , which would plus up funding for civilian nuclear research and development.

Supporters say both bills will aid national security by decreasing U.S. reliance on foreign mineral and energy production.

The nuclear legislation has broad bipartisan backing despite some concerns from environmental groups, who argue that it could stymie the renewable energy transition. Sen. Cory Booker, a Green New Deal signatory, is the lead Democrat on the legislation.

But the mineral legislation facing a steeper uphill climb. Lawmakers and experts continue to lock horns over the environmental rollbacks in the law and the need for domestic production, rather than simply shifting import supply chains away from China. U.S. production of critical minerals has tanked since the country led the world decades ago.

The House Natural Resources Committee will also hold a virtual hearing Monday titled The U.S. Park Police Attack on Peaceful Protesters at Lafayette Square. Park police cleared out protestors near the park in front of the White House on June 1 to pave the way for President Trump to stage a photo-op outside of St. John s Church.

HEALTH

The Trump administration last week filed a brief to the Supreme Court arguing that the entirety of the Affordable Care Act should be knocked down. The Justice Department said because the individual mandate penalty was removed, the rest of the law is invalidated.

The entire ACA thus must fall with the individual mandate, the administration states.

Vice President Mike Pence said Friday during a press briefing with the Coronavirus Task Force that there may be a tendency among the American people to think that we are back to that place that we were two months. We re in a much better place.

COVID-19 cases, meanwhile, continue to climb in states such as Florida, Texas, and Oklahoma.

We want the American people to understand that it s almost inarguable that more testing is generating more cases, said Pence. To one extent or another, the volume of new cases coming in is a reflection of a great success in expanding testing across the country.

Top health officials will update members of the Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee on Tuesday about the federal government s response to COVID-19. The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases Director Anthony Fauci, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Director Robert Redfield, Health and Human Services Assistant Secretary for Health Brett Giroir, and Food and Drug Administration Commissioner Stephen Hahn will testify.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will also have a hearing via videoconferencing on the U.S. international pandemic preparedness and response.

The Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee holds a hearing to look at COVID-19 s impact on the U.S. territories. House members representing the Northern Mariana Islands, American Samoa, U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, and Guam will testify.

In the House, the Energy and Commerce Health Subcommittee will have a remote hearing Tuesday on a slew of legislation to address mental health, including the Telemental Health Expansion Act, the Suicide Prevention Act, and the Mental Health Parity Compliance Act.

The COVID-19 response in American Indian communities will be evaluated during an oversight hearing with the Senate Indian Affairs Committee on Wednesday. Senators will also consider legislation to expand the Federal Tort Claims Act coverage to urban Indian health organizations, which are currently not included and have to cover liability costs.

Then on Thursday, the Senate appropriations subcommittee with oversight of the Health and Human Services Department will look at Operation Warp Speed, the Trump administration s initiative to rapidly develop and distribute a COVID-19 vaccine. Senators will hear from Redfield, National Institutes of Health Director Francis Collins, and Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority Acting Directory Gary Disbrow.

TAXES AND TRADE

The Senate Finance Committee will hold a hearing Tuesday on the impact of COVID-19 on the 2020 tax-filing season. IRS Commissioner Charles Rettig is the sole witness.

The IRS already pushed back the April 15 filing deadline to July 15, but is considering moving it again to Sept. 15, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin told Bloomberg last week.

The hearing also comes on the heels of a Government Accountability office report released last week showing that the Treasury Department and IRS made coronavirus stimulus payments of up to $1,200 each to more than a million deceased individuals.

The Finance Committee s subcommittee on international trade, customs and global competitiveness will hear from experts Tuesday on how censorship can be a nontariff barrier to trade. The hearing will in part focus on how countries such as China can enact restrictive laws or regulations around digital content created or hosted by U.S. tech companies.

Actor Richard Gere is set to testify in his capacity as chairman of the International Campaign for Tibet. The hearing was postponed from March 3.

TECHNOLOGY

The congressional effort to reform Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, big tech s primary legal shield, is set to move forward in a big way on Thursday. The Senate Judiciary Committee plans to mark up the EARN IT Act, legislation that ties the tech platforms legal liability protections to government-approved efforts to combat child sex abuse material online. The bill is controversial, not least because it s viewed by many as a backdoor for the federal government to break end-to-end encryption techniques.

A separate, more moderate Section 230 reform effort supported by top members of the Senate Commerce Committee was also introduced last week, suggesting lawmakers could soon split along committee lines.

The Senate Finance Subcommittee on International Trade, Customs, and Global Competitiveness meets Tuesday for a hearing into how the online-censorship practices of China and other authoritarian countries constitutes a nontariff barrier to international trade. As the trade war between Washington and Beijing escalated, the U.S. tech industry has become increasingly vocal about Chinese censorship laws they say deny digital platforms and services the opportunity to compete in the Chinese marketplace.

Monday s marathon markup in the House Rules Committee of the INVEST Act a massive infrastructure bill being pushed by House Democrats includes several amendments designed to boost broadband deployment in rural and underserved areas. The original bill already sets aside billions in additional funding for broadband infrastructure projects, a longtime policy goal for lawmakers in both parties.

The House Small Business Subcommittee on Economic Growth, Tax, and Capital Access meets Thursday for a hearing on supply chain resiliency, a key issue for a U.S. tech industry heavily dependent on equipment and components manufactured in China and other nations still roiled by the spread of COVID-19.

The Senate Committee on Banking, House, and Urban Affairs meets Tuesday for a hearing on the digitization of money and payments.

WHITE HOUSE

President Trump has few events on his public schedule as he heads into the week ending in Independence Day celebrations in South Dakota and Washington. On Thursday, he speaks at what the White House is calling a spirit of America showcase. On Friday, he flies to Keystone, South Dakota to observe fireworks at Mount Rushmore. On Saturday, he is back at the White House to address July Fourth revelers on the South Lawn.

urn:contentItem:5X40-S2B1-JBNW-31XK-00000-00Outlook: Congress To Wrap Up Stop-Gap Funding Before Shutdown Deadline2019-09-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisOutlook: Congress To Wrap Up Stop-Gap Funding Before Shutdown DeadlineZach C. Cohen, Casey Wooten

Congress is eyeing the exits, but there are a few mandatory items on the agenda before the end of the September work period.

The Senate this week must pass a continuing resolution to fund the government and avert an Oct. 1 shutdown before it leaves town for a two-week recess. The House passed the CR last week, 301-123.

The CR is necessary because neither chamber approved all 12 funding bills in time. The House has passed 10 of them so far, but the Senate hasn t passed any. The Senate Appropriations Committee passed four of their bills unanimously this month, but Democrats last week blocked a package of defense and domestic appropriations bills touched by President Trump s push to fund physical barriers on the southern border.

Senate appropriators in the meantime are scheduled to mark up legislation for the Homeland Security, Interior, and Justice Departments as well as the Environmental Protection Agency in subcommittee meetings Tuesday before the full committee considers those bills as well as that for Congress's funding Thursday.

I hope we can reboot this process and move forward for the sake of our Senate process, for the sake of stable funding for the federal government, and for the sake of our nation's security, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said Thursday.

The Senate is also expected to vote on a privileged resolution ending Trump s emergency declaration that authorized the reprogramming of military construction funds to pay for border barriers. The Pentagon has diverted   over $1 billion from domestic projects, but the resolution s supporters said last week they anticipate the final result will be similar to when the same gambit failed to garner the two-thirds majority necessary to overturn Trump s first veto.

The House will also tackle border issues this week when it takes up Rep. Veronica Escobar s bill tightening oversight of Homeland Security Department programs on the border. House leaders pulled the bill in July after other immigration measures were added to the legislation in committee, prompting pushback from some moderate Democrats.

It became more of an immigration bill than a DHS oversight bill in the process, and the bigger it got, the harder it was to try to get quick agreement on it to move, Escobar said Thursday.

The bill is now pared to its original form and Democrats will pursue the other immigration issues separately, Escobar said. The House will also take up Rep. Lauren Underwood s U.S. Border Patrol Medical Screening Standards Act, which sets tighter medical standards when caring for immigrants at the border.

The Senate s first order of business Monday will be breaking the filibuster on Brian McGuire s nomination to be a deputy undersecretary at the Treasury Department. McConnell had planned to do so Thursday after McGuire, a former McConnell chief of staff, passed out the Finance Committee in July with only Democratic Sen. Bob Casey objecting. But fellow Kentucky Republican Sen. Rand Paul blocked McConnell s request to expedite the confirmation.

For many years, Senator Paul has advocated to amend tax treaties to protect the privacy of American citizens, a Paul spokesman said. Recently, the Department of Treasury has been less than responsive, and Senator Paul has decided to vote against some of their nominees. There is no animosity toward this specific nominee.

McConnell on Thursday also teed up votes to confirm a number of executive-branch nominees, including Joseph Cella s bid to be ambassador to five Pacific island nations, Daniel Jorjani to be the Interior Department s solicitor, and David Black to be a deputy commissioner of Social Security.

Nomination work will also continue in committee. The HELP Committee will meet Tuesday to consider advancing Eugene Scalia s nomination as Labor secretary. McConnell s office said Friday that his nomination, as well as that of Air Force Gen. John Hyten s bid to be vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff despite allegations of sexual misconduct , could see floor action as soon as this week.

The Judiciary Committee on Thursday is also expected to advance six district-judge nominees and 5th Circuit nominee Sul Ozerden, despite some Republicans skepticism of the potential appeals judge.

I think he ll make it, Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham said of Ozerden.

In the House, the Judiciary Committee s schedule is packed. The panel will hold a hearing on banning assault weapons Wednesday. Rep. David Cicilline is close to getting the key 218 cosponsors for his assault-weapons bill and has been seeking more moderate Democrats to sign on to the legislation.

Judiciary will also convene hearings on potential presidential violations of the emoluments clause, oversight of the administration s failed ban on immigrants from majority Muslim countries, and voting-rights issues.

The full House will take its first votes Tuesday rather than Monday to accommodate funeral arrangements for Emily Clyburn, House Majority Whip James Clyburn s wife, who died Thursday.

The House Intelligence Committee is set for a blockbuster hearing Thursday as acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire is set to testify on the whistleblower complaint related to the Trump administration s contact with an undisclosed foreign leader.

Less likely to hit the Senate floor before a two-week recess is any legislation to address the recent spate of mass shootings that marred the summer state-work period. Senate Republicans still await word from the White House on what Trump would support, as lawmakers continue to push for modification to existing background-check and red-flag laws .

The longer it goes, the more difficult it becomes, said Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin.

Here s what else is on tap this week:

DEFENSE AND FOREIGN POLICY

House and Senate conferees continue formal negotiations over the massive National Defense Authorization Act this week.

The committees still hopes to complete the legislation by the end of the month, but will have to hash out agreements on a number of sticking points, the most prominent being whether to allow border construction with Pentagon funds. The issue derailed the defense appropriations package last week.

Other hot-button issues include whether to backfill accounts diverted for border construction, fund new low-yield nuclear weapons, stand up the Space Force as the sixth branch of the military, and whether to prohibit funding for war with Iran. The Senate will vote on a number of nonbinding motions to instruct conferees on the most controversial issues this week. Senate Armed Services Committee chairman Jim Inhofe has reportedly prepared a slimmed down package if the conferees cannot resolve the disputes.

The bills are very similar except for where they re different, House Armed Services Committee chair Adam Smith quipped to reporters Thursday, before conferees held their first official meeting.

The Senate and House foreign-affairs committees mark up the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act this week. Speaker Pelosi told reporters that she intends to move the bill as soon as possible.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee marks up several other bills at its business hearing on Wednesday, which would add wildlife trafficking to the State Department s whistleblower reward program, penalize governments that sever diplomatic ties with Taiwan in favor of China, commit funding for marine debris reduction, and reauthorize the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom.

The House Foreign Affairs Committee marks up non-binding resolutions that condemn China s interference in Hong Kong s affairs, support global health funding, and call for the release of United States citizen Paul Whelan from Russia.

Back in the Senate, Sen. Mitt Romney calls cochairs of the Syria Study Group, Michael Singh and Dana Stroul, to testify Wednesday on the report to the Near East, South Asia, Central Asia and Counterterrorism Subcommittee. The same day, the full committee hears from State Department officials on how U.S. policy in Mexico and Central America affects migration to the U.S. Mexico border.

ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT

Lawmakers are aiming to polish off a fiscal 2020 defense-authorization bill this week, and the legislation could be a change in federal regulation of a family of chemicals that scientists claim causes a wide range of illness and even death.

The House and Senate authorization bills, which lawmakers are now reconciling, both prohibit by 2023 the military use of firefighting foams that contain per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances, often referred to as PFAS.

Still, those negotiating a final bill will have to muscle past White House and chemical-industry opposition to the PFAS phaseouts. The PFAS family, dubbed forever chemicals due to the unique length of time they stay in human bodies and the environment, are known for their heat-resistant and nonstick properties.

Public-health officials, however, say groundwater and other contamination leads to liver damage, cancer, and other adverse health effects.

Democrats, along with some Republicans, are also pushing language on the defense-authorization bill to designate all PFAS as hazardous chemicals under Superfund law, which could lead to huge cleanup liabilities for the private sector. That language passed as part of the House legislation.

Meanwhile, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell teed up a top Interior Department nomination for floor confirmation this week. Daniel Jorjani, the acting DOI solicitor, is tapped to take over the post permanently. Senators from both sides of the aisle have criticized Jorjani for revising Freedom of Information Act policy to limit mandatory responses.

Also in the Senate, the Energy and Natural Resources Committee will mark up several bills Wednesday that supporters say could play a critical in curbing greenhouse-gas emissions. The Energy Savings and Industrial Competitiveness Act of 2019, legislation known as Portman-Shaheen, will be on the agenda, as will the Better Energy Storage Technology Act.

Portman-Shaheen, led by Sens. Rob Portman and Jeanne Shaheen, is a perennial bill that boosts building-code standards and strengthens public-private partnerships designed to limit energy use in manufacturing processes. The Best Act, sponsored by Sens. Susan Collins and Martin Heinrich, among others, would boost Energy Department research into batteries and other energy storage, which is currently an impediment to renewable energy-deployment.

And a Senate Appropriations subcommittee will mark up the upper chamber s fiscal 2020 Interior Department and Environmental Protection Agency spending bill Tuesday. That account is traditionally one of the most controversial, but last year senators rallied together to pass a bipartisan bill out of committee.

On the House side, the Natural Resources Committee will hold a hearing Thursday to examine The Department of the Interior s Failure to Cooperate with Congressional Oversight Requests. Committee Chairman Raul Grijalva has recently threatened to subpoena the department over plans to relocate Bureau of Land Management headquarters in Grand Junction, Colorado. Witnesses are not yet named.

HEALTH

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi s legislation to lower drug prices is finally here. Pelosi, along with the Ways and Means and Energy and Commerce Committee chairs, rolled out the proposal last week that would allow the Health and Human Services Department to negotiate drug prices. Energy and Commerce Committee Republicans immediately blasted the plan as a socialist proposal to appease her most extreme members.

But President Trump did not echo this rhetoric. I like Sen. Grassley s drug pricing bill very much, and it s great to see Speaker Pelosi s bill today. Let s get it done in a bipartisan way! he tweeted.

Now, the Energy and Commerce Health Subcommittee will hold a hearing on Pelosi s bill and a few other drug-pricing bills on Wednesday. On Thursday, the House Education & Labor Committee's Health, Employment, Labor, and Pensions Subcommittee will convene a hearing on lowering drug prices and increasing transparency.

House lawmakers will also examine the health risks associated with e-cigarettes. On Tuesday, the House Oversight and Reform Committee s Economic and Consumer Policy Subcommittee will look at the outbreak of lung illness connected to e-cigarettes, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report that youth use of the products has risen. The next day, the Energy and Commerce Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee will also look at the public-health threat of e-cigarettes.

The House Appropriations Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Subcommittee will have a hearing Wednesday morning on the international food-assistance programs at the Agriculture Department and the U.S. Agency for International Development.

The same morning, the House Appropriations Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, Education and Related Agencies Subcommittee will discuss investments in medical research at health institutes. Witnesses include directors of the National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences, National Library of Medicine, National Institutes of Health, National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health, National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities and National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering.

To wrap up the week, the House Ways and Means Oversight Subcommittee will hold a hearing Thursday on the public-health consequences and costs of gun violence.

TAXES AND TRADE

The House Ways and Means Committee has a full plate of health care, trade, and tax legislation. Moving those bills, however, has been complicated.

The committee has yet to say when or if it will take up Rep. Bill Pascrell s legislation to repeal the state-and-local-tax-deduction cap implemented as part of the 2017 tax-code overhaul. Committee Chairman Richard Neal has said he s open to the legislation.

Pascrell said last week that they re working on a compromise and the repeal would be temporary, perhaps for two years.

But Pascrell will still need to convince other Democrats that the repeal won t be a giveaway to taxpayers in expensive homes.

I think some action needs to be taken about SALT, but what that action is, raises questions of, Is it fully paid for? Ways and Means member Rep. Lloyd Doggett asked last week. Is it fully paid for by those at the top that are getting most of the benefits individually from a SALT repeal?

Doggett said there will be more discussion on the issue.

House Democratic members of the working group designated to negotiate a compromise on the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement continue talks with U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer.

The working group sat down with Lighthizer on Friday to discuss his response to Democratic proposals which Lighthizer submitted to the working group in mid-September.

Neal told reporters Thursday that we ve made headway with the USMCA, but there are still some outstanding issues. Republicans had wanted to reach a deal by the end of this month, but Democrats are not following that schedule. House Democrats just launched a major prescription-drug-pricing plan that could compete for attention with any USMCA implementing bill, but Neal said the committee can handle the workload.

We re going to sequence these as they fall into line, but I also think that we ve made headway on the trade issue, USMCA, and we don t want to get too far out front, we need some additional agreement with the USTR, but the conversations have been very sound, Neal said.

There are no hearings scheduled in the Senate Finance Committee.

TECHNOLOGY

The congressional effort to spur antitrust enforcers to tackle the tech industry continues apace this week. The Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Antitrust will meet Tuesday with Bruce Hoffman, the director of the Federal Trade Commission s Bureau of Competition, for a hearing to examine competition in digital technology markets.

FTC Chairman Joe Simons received an earful last week from the same subcommittee for his agency s perceived failure to take big tech to task, and Hoffman is unlikely to fair much better. If last week is any indication, Hoffman may even be forced to make the case that the FTC be allowed to keep the federal antitrust authorities it now shares with the Justice Department.

The full Senate Judiciary Committee meets Thursday for a markup, where lawmakers will consider advancing legislation requiring the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office to ask for demographic data from patent applicants and to make that data public. Sponsored by Sens. Thom Tillis and Mazie Hirono, the IDEA Act is designed to help researchers better understand and hopefully work to close gender, racial and income gaps in patent application rates.

The House Committee on Science, Space and Technology will meet Tuesday with representatives from the National Science Foundation and others to discuss the potential disruptions artificial intelligence may cause to workforces of the future. On Thursday, the committee will take a look at the problem of online imposters and disinformation from a scientific perspective, meeting with computer scientists from academic institutions and industry to discuss an issue that grows daily in importance ahead of the 2020 elections.

The Federal Communications Commission will hold its monthly open meeting on Thursday. Among other initiatives, the commission will consider allocating $950 million in subsidies for fixed and mobile-broadband-internet support for Puerto Rico. The island territory has struggled with broadband connection issues ever since Hurricane Maria hit the island in 2017.

WHITE HOUSE

This is United Nations week for Trump, who will not return to Washington from New York until Thursday.

On Monday, he will snub the UN Climate Action summit for his own meeting on religious persecution. On Tuesday, he will address the opening of the General Assembly. From Monday through Wednesday he has scheduled one-on-one meetings with 12 foreign leaders, none more important than the sit-down on Wednesday with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, whose July phone conversation with Trump has plunged the White House into controversy.

On Thursday, he will headline a Republican fundraiser before returning to Washington. On Friday, he will speak at an Hispanic Heritage Month reception and he will mark the Jewish high holy days. Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish new year, begins at sundown Sept. 29.

urn:contentItem:5VR6-2JK1-JBNW-30NM-00000-00Outlook: Dems Call for Full Release of Mueller Report2019-03-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisOutlook: Dems Call for Full Release of Mueller ReportDaniel Newhauser, Zach C. Cohen

Special Counsel Robert Mueller has completed his investigation into Russian interference into the 2016 election in favor of President Trump. And lawmakers want to know every word of Mueller's final report.

Congress requires the full report and the underlying documents so that the Committees can proceed with their independent work, including oversight and legislating to address any issues the Mueller report may raise, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said in a joint statement on Sunday. The American people have a right to know.

Democrats are clamoring for the full release of the report, which found no evidence Trump or his associates purposefully colluded with the Russian government s documented efforts to interfere in the 2016 presidential election. Mueller said his report does not exonerate Trump on the question of obstruction of justice, but Attorney General William Barr said he and outgoing Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein concluded that the investigation is not sufficient to establish such a charge.

Barr said in a letter Sunday to the judiciary committees of both chambers that he as quickly as possible would release as much of the Special Counsel report as I can consistent with Department of Justice policies and applicable law.

Congressional committees will also continue to investigate the Trump administration, picking up where Mueller left off. Chairman Jerrold Nadler said Sunday that the House Judiciary Committee will be calling Attorney General Barr in to testify in the near future.

I appreciate the Attorney General s goal of producing as much information as possible, consistent with the law. I look forward to reviewing that information," said Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell.

The rest of Congress business remains on the calendar. The House will take a historic vote this week to override Trump s first-ever veto, of a resolution terminating his emergency order to finance a border wall.

The measure is expected to fall short of the two-thirds threshold needed to override a veto, as only 13 Republicans joined Democrats to pass the measure in the House last month. Even if it does somehow pass, the Senate is not expected to have enough votes to override a veto either.

Meanwhile, the Senate is expected to vote down a comprehensive solution to averting the worst effects of climate change, before immediately turning to a stopgap measure meant to pick up the pieces of its devastation. McConnell before the recess teed up a procedural vote on the Green New Deal, a nonbinding resolution laying out Democrats ambitious agenda to curb the effects of climate change. Following its expected failure , the Senate will consider a House-passed   relief package sponsored by Senate Republicans providing $13.6 billion to recover from last year s hurricanes, wildfires, and other natural disasters.

The Senate kicks off the week Monday with a procedural vote on Bridget Bade s nomination to sit on the 9th Circuit. Bade, a magistrate judge for the District of Arizona and former assistant U.S. attorney in Phoenix, successfully passed out of the Senate Judiciary Committee last month with the support of all Republicans and some senior Democrats. Then on Thursday, the Energy and Natural Resources Committee will   consider Acting Interior Secretary David Bernhardt s full nomination for the job he has performed since Ryan Zinke stepped down.

After the veto-override vote, the House will turn its attention to gender-equality issues. The body will vote on the Paycheck Fairness Act, a measure that would update the Equal Pay Act to try to narrow the gender pay gap. Later in the week, the House will vote on a resolution disapproving of Trump s decision to bar transgender people from serving in the military.

The Senate Commerce Aviation and Space Subcommittee will also hold an oversight hearing on Wednesday with testimony from federal transportation officials in light of recent Boeing 737 Max aircraft crashes.

Here s what else is on tap this week:

DEFENSE AND FOREIGN POLICY

Acting Defense Secretary Patrick Shanahan and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Joseph Dunford testify Tuesday to the House Armed Services Committee on the Pentagon s 2020 budget request. Democrats are likely to focus on Trump s decision to divert funding for the construction of a border wall. Marine Commandant Gen. Robert Neller recently warned in a leaked letter that the diversion of funds is causing unacceptable risk" to combat readiness. The Pentagon has not released a definitive list of projects that would be defunded.

Shanahan is also embroiled in a scandal of his own, which Democrats may seize on. The Pentagon inspector general launched an investigation Wednesday into whether Shanahan promoted his former employer of three decades, Boeing, over companies competing for government contracts. Shanahan has recused himself from any matters involving the company since entering government, and has pledged to cooperate with the investigation.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo testifies to the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Wednesday, another hearing primed for controversy. Pompeo has not testified to the House since May of last year, when the chamber was still in Republican control.

The purported purpose of the hearing, the State Department s 2020 budget request, is also likely to generate fireworks. As in prior budget requests, Trump has called for dramatic cuts to the international-affairs budget that Congress is unlikely to authorize.

Before the Pompeo hearing, the committee holds four hearings Tuesday on the Trump administration s proposal to alter regulations on firearms exports, corruption in South America, U.S. Africa relations, and the U.S. Europe relationship.

The Armed Services Committee holds its more routine policy hearings after Shanahan s testimony on Tuesday morning. Later that afternoon, the Seapower and Projection Forces Subcommittee hears testimony from Navy officials on the 2020 budget. On Wednesday, Commander Adm. Philip Davidson of U.S. Indo-Pacific Command testifies on activity in the region, and the Military Personnel Subcommittee hears testimony on compensation and duty status for reservists.

The Strategic Forces Subcommittee holds a hearing Thursday on the Pentagon s nuclear policy in fiscal 2020, and the Intelligence and Emerging Threats and Capabilities Subcommittee gets an update on the Pentagon s 2020 budget request for science and technology programs.

In the Senate, the most notable witness is Energy Secretary Rick Perry, who testifies Thursday on the Energy Department s atomic-energy defense programs.

His testimony is part of a busy week for the Senate Armed Services Committee, which holds five hearings. Members will hear Tuesday from Army Secretary Mark Esper and Chief of Staff Mark Milley on the Army s 2020 budget and the Future Years Defense Program, and from cyberspace-industry experts on the defense industrial base. Top Navy officials testify Wednesday to the Seapower Subcommittee on the Navy s shipbuilding plans and the 2020 budget, and Air Force officials speak to the Strategic Forces Subcommittee on the space program.

The Foreign Relations Committee holds hearings Tuesday on Russia's involvement in the long-simmering Ukraine conflict, and on U.S. policy toward North Korea.

And the committee considers three nominees on Wednesday, including two top positions in the understaffed State Department: Brigadier Gen. David Stilwell to be assistant secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, and Robert Destro to be assistant secretary for Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor.

ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT

Many Democrats are already signaling they ll vote present on the controversial Green New Deal resolution , a maneuver they deployed last Congress on a Medicare-for-all vote, and one that s gotten the OK from backers of action on climate change. Meanwhile, Republicans are feverishly highlighting the specific proposals in the resolution. Speaking on the Senate floor earlier this month, McConnell called the Green New Deal garden-variety 20th-century socialism.

When the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee holds its confirmation hearing Thursday for Acting Interior Secretary Bernhardt, Democrats, who have called for the Interior Department to release more information about its anticipated offshore-drilling plan, are expected to highlight Bernhardt s work as an energy-industry lobbyist.

In the House, the Natural Resources Committee will hear from Interior officials Wednesday on the 2020 budget.

The same day, the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Water and Power Subcommittee holds a hearing on the Colorado River drought contingency plan, which states are pushing for Congress to implement. The House Natural Resources Water, Oceans, and Wildlife Subcommittee will meet on the same issue Thursday morning. That subcommittee also meets Tuesday for a legislative hearing regarding several bills on wildlife conservation.

On Tuesday afternoon, the House Natural Resources Energy and Mineral Resources Subcommittee will discuss the need to protect the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge coastal plain. The subcommittee also holds a hearing Thursday on abandoned-mine reclamation.

On Thursday, the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee will meet to examine the federal response to the risks associated with per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances, or PFAS.

HEALTH

The Trump administration s goal to promote work requirements in Medicaid hangs in the balance as D.C. District Court Judge James Boasberg is expected this week to issue a decision around the legality of Kentucky s and Arkansas s work requirements. Arkansas has received a lot of attention over the implementation of its program since more than 18,000 beneficiaries were disenrolled from the system in 2018 due to noncompliance with the new requirements.

On Tuesday, the House Budget Committee will be looking at the Health and Human Services Department's 2020 budget.

The Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee will also hold a hearing on the implementation of the 21st Century Cures Act to improve the exchange of electronic health information. The hearing will focus on two recent rules issued by HHS to define information blocking and to give patients more control over their records.

On Thursday, the Senate Appropriations Committee agriculture and Food and Drug Administration subcommittee will have a hearing on the FDA s 2020 budget with outgoing Commissioner Scott Gottlieb.

TAXES & TRADE

As filing season enters its final month, some taxpayers are still left wondering what will become of the 30-some expired tax breaks known as extenders.

Senate Finance Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley and ranking member Ron Wyden recently introduced legislation renewing the extenders for the 2018 and 2019 tax years, but in an interview with Vox last week, Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said Democrats will expect concessions to move an extenders bill, pointing to environmental and infrastructure issues as possible points of compromise.

The House Ways and Means Trade Subcommittee is holding a hearing Tuesday on creating and enforcing trade rules to benefit American workers.

The next day, the full committee will examine the 2017 tax law, one of a series of hearings looking at the impact of the GOP's overhaul.

No Senate Finance Committee hearings are scheduled for this week.

On trade, Trump told the Fox Business Network in an interview aired Friday that a deal with China is getting very close. Chinese officials have said f are set to hold meetings in China March 28 and 29, Reuters reported Thursday. A meeting between Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping has been postponed from March until at least April, however.

The Trump administration received a Commerce Department report weeks ago on whether it can impose national security tariffs on auto imports, but hasn t released the document or announced a decision on whether to move forward with the tariffs. Some trade analysts have said that the administration may be waiting until a deal with China is finalized before announcing a decision.

In his Fox Business interview, Trump said the auto and auto-part imports do not pose a security risk. That, however, is likely not an indication of whether he will move forward with the tariffs.

What poses a security risk is our balance sheet, he said. We need a strong balance sheet; otherwise you don t have national security.

TECHNOLOGY

As the Senate looks to wrap up negotiations over draft data-privacy legislation, lawmakers want to hear from some industry players other than Facebook, Google, and the rest of the major tech platforms.

On Tuesday, the Senate Commerce Manufacturing, Trade, and Consumer Protection Subcommittee will meet for a hearing on how a federal privacy law would impact small businesses. Senators will hear from several business representatives, including from the real-estate industry and the start-up community. While most of the discussion around data privacy in Washington has centered on the misuse of personal data by Silicon Valley, experts have warned that small businesses could be hurt by compliance costs imposed via strict privacy rules. Sen. Jerry Moran, the subcommittee's chairman, recently suggested those rules could be tweaked to accommodate small businesses.

The House Energy and Commerce Communications and Technology Subcommittee meets Tuesday to mark up the Save the Internet Act, the Democratic House's push to restore the net-neutrality protections repealed by the Trump administration's Federal Communications Commission in 2017. If prior hearings on the legislation are any indication, the markup is almost certain to end in a party-line vote. Republican lawmakers have attacked the Democrats for the way they went about drafting the legislation, and are almost universally opposed to the bill's provision that internet service providers be placed back under the utility-style regulatory structure of Title II of the Communications Act.

The Energy and Commerce Consumer Protection Subcommittee meets Thursday to discuss ways to enhance vehicle technology to prevent drunk driving. While ignition interlock devices are likely to take up a significant amount of the committee s bandwidth, expect at least a few members to raise the benefits of self-driving vehicles as a way to cut down on drunk-driving accidents.

The Federal Trade Commission is taking a two-day look at how its enforcement priorities on issues such as privacy, information-sharing, antitrust, and artificial intelligence stack up against a fast-changing international regulatory framework on technology. Starting Monday, the FTC will hear from a slew of tech experts on the impact of different approaches to tech regulation and how commissioners can work with foreign regulators and smooth over disputes on data-sharing, antitrust, and other hot-button tech topics.

The hearings continue the commission s months-long review of its antitrust and privacy policies in light of new concerns surrounding the pervasive influence of big tech in the American economy.

The Senate Armed Services Cybersecurity Subcommittee is scheduled to examine the cybersecurity responsibilities of the defense industrial base on Tuesday. Recent reports have suggested an extensive hacking campaign by the Chinese government against American arms manufacturers, and lawmakers are likely to grill industry representatives on the protections they ve put in place to guard sensitive technological secrets from such attacks.

The House Judiciary Courts, Intellectual Property, and the Internet Subcommittee meets Wednesday for a hearing on the lack of diversity in patents and inventorship and its effect on innovation in the U.S.

WHITE HOUSE

President Trump starts the week focused on the politics of a close ally and ends it tending to his own politics. On Monday morning, he will meet with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is locked in a close reelection battle back home and hopes for a boost from Trump, who is very popular in Israel. Trump closes the day by welcoming to the White House the reigning Stanley Cup champions of the National Hockey League, the Washington Capitals. On Tuesday, he will have dinner with Netanyahu. On Wednesday, he will present the Medal of Honor posthumously to Army Staff Sgt. Travis W. Atkins, who sacrificed his own life in Iraq in 2007 when he threw himself on an insurgent just as he was detonating a bomb strapped to his body; his action saved the lives of three other American soldiers. On Thursday, the president will go to Grand Rapids, Michigan, for one of his large political rallies designed to help him win a second term.
