urn:contentItem:5R3P-3R91-JBNW-33M7-00000-00Outlook: High-Stakes Talks on Taxes and Spending2017-12-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisOutlook: High-Stakes Talks on Taxes and SpendingAlex Rogers, Casey Wooten

Before attempting to pass a once-in-a-generation tax overhaul by Christmas, Congress must turn to the urgent matter of passing a bill to avert a partial government shutdown by its Friday-night deadline.

Last week, President Trump tweeted that he didn t see a deal coming together with Democrats because they want illegal immigrants flooding into our Country unchecked, are weak on Crime and want to substantially RAISE Taxes, he said in a tweet. Senate and House Democratic leaders Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi responded to the affront by backing out of a scheduled meeting with Trump, saying they d work with Republican congressional leaders instead. Trump has said privately that a government shutdown could be politically beneficial, according to The Washington Post , even though Republicans in Congress disagree.

Democrats have argued that they want to see an increase in domestic programs as well as a funding boost for the military. They also want to provide funding for the Children s Health Insurance Program, which provides services to 9 million children, and the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program that provides temporary legal protection to hundreds of thousands of immigrants brought to the United States as children. Republicans have debated whether to pass a short-term deal for a couple of weeks or longer.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said on This Week that a government shutdown would not occur. It's just not going to happen, he said.

McConnell also said it s ridiculous to not support a year-end deal that doesn t address DACA, since Trump has given Congress a March deadline for when recipients would be at risk for deportation. There is no crisis, he said.

But on Face the Nation , White House Office of Management and Budget Director Mick Mulvaney said that the overall congressional appropriations process, in which massive legislation passes all at one time or fails all at one time, is sort of managing by crisis to crisis. He then laid out all of the competing factions in Congress that threaten a shutdown.

I think there's a group of right-wingers in the House who say they want to shut the government down, said Mulvaney. There's a group of Democrats who want to shut the government down over DACA. And there's a group of lawmakers from some of the hurricane states who want to shut the government down until they get what they want.

This just sheds light on the fact that the appropriations, the spending system is broken when any little group can sort of hold the government hostage, he added. We need to get beyond that. I think that we will, I don't think you'll see a government shutdown.

On Monday, the Senate will continue churning through nominees, holding a vote to consider Kirstjen Nielsen as Homeland Security secretary, a position left vacant once John Kelly left in July to become Trump s chief of staff. Nielsen was Kelly s top aide at DHS.

The House, meanwhile, will take up the Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act, a top priority of gun-rights groups that is strongly opposed by gun-control organizations. The chamber is also reportedly planning to consider a bill to fix the National Instant Criminal Background Check System, though that measure was not on the House s schedule for this week as of Sunday evening.

At the same time, the two chambers will begin ironing out the differences between their two tax-reform bills. House leaders have scheduled a vote Monday evening to move to a conference committee, and the Senate will eventually appoint conferees as well.

Here s what else is on tap:

DEFENSE AND FOREIGN POLICY

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will hold a hearing with outside experts Tuesday on the shared authority between the executive and legislative branches over international accords.

As it continues investigating Russian interference in the 2016 election, the Senate Intelligence Committee is set to hold closed briefings on Tuesday and Thursday.

On Wednesday, the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee is scheduled to meet for a hearing on evolving international terrorist threats. Officials from the Defense, Homeland Security, and Justice departments, as well as from the director of National Intelligence's office, are slated to testify.

Elsewhere, the Senate Armed Services Committee will hold a hearing Thursday on the Defense Department's acquisition-reform efforts. The undersecretary of Defense for acquisition, technology, and logistics and the secretaries of the Army, Navy, and Air Force are set to appear before the panel.

That same day, the House Foreign Affairs Committee is scheduled to have a hearing on counterterrorism efforts in Africa featuring officials from the Defense and State departments.

ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT

Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Scott Pruitt will head to Capitol Hill on Thursday for the first time since his combative Senate confirmation process. Expect Republicans to praise his track record, such as initiating the repeal of the Clean Power Plan, while Democrats criticize his campaign to roll back environmental regulations.

Pruitt's work at the EPA is largely applauded among Republicans, but at least one of those lawmakers, Rep. Ryan Costello, is trying to sit in on the Energy and Commerce subcommittee panel to challenge the administrator's decision to bar former recipients of EPA grants to fill slots on the agency's advisory committees.

The House energy committee will also host the Energy Department's top electricity-grid official, Bruce Walker, on Friday to discuss the department's efforts to combat cybersecurity threats. Many lawmakers have been sounding alarm bells about grid vulnerability. Meanwhile, a House Natural Resources subcommittee will hold a hearing Thursday on updating the Interior Department's mission.

The Senate energy committee will hear testimony Tuesday from second-tier Energy and Interior department nominees. The Senate could move this week on House-passed legislation to overhaul the EPA's brownfields program.

HEALTH

The Senate Republicans tax-reform bill may have hit snags on the way to the vote, but the provision to effectively repeal the individual mandate was locked down after Sen. Susan Collins received some guarantees on legislation to provide cost-sharing-reduction payments and reinsurance funding would be passed separately. Some experts are not so convinced that these measures would offset the uncertainty brought to the market by getting rid of the penalty that consumers incurred if they do not obtain health insurance.

Lawmakers also have to fund the government by the end of Friday. A continuing resolution released by the House Rules Committee contains a short-term patch for CHIP to cover an emergency shortfall state for the rest of the year. Funding for the program ran out at the end of September.

Members of the Senate Appropriations Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies Subcommittee will have a hearing Tuesday on the prevention, treatment, and recovery from the opioid crisis.

The Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee will hear from leaders of the National Institutes of Health and the Food and Drug Administration about the implementation of the 21st Century Cures Act.

TAXES

The GOP effort to overhaul the tax code has officially gotten further than their failed bid to repeal the Affordable Care Act earlier this year.

With the 51-49 Senate passage of its tax bill early Saturday morning Sen. Bob Corker was the sole no vote among Republicans the big question now is how lawmakers will resolve the differences between that bill and the House version, which breezed through that chamber in November.

Getting the Senate bill passed took some last-minute dealmaking, and lawmakers were massaging legislative language well into Friday night. There were 11th-hour provisions for Collins to allow a deduction for up to $10,000 in property tax and another for Sen. Ron Johnson to boost the income deduction for pass-through businesses to 23 percent from 17.4 percent.

The state and local property tax tweak likely won t meet much resistance among House members. In fact, the deduction is essentially a requirement to move the bill in that chamber, as 30-odd GOP lawmakers from high-tax states such as New York and New Jersey rallied to get the same provision inserted into their version and won t likely vote for a bill that doesn t contain something similar.

The pay-fors and the pass-through rate could be the sticking point, though.

The Senate bill delays a corporate rate cut from 35 percent to 20 percent for one year, starting it in 2019. That s something that House conservatives like Freedom Caucus Chairman Mark Meadows have opposed, calling the idea dead on arrival in early November.

The House version has a vastly different structure for dealing with pass-through entities, businesses that pass their profits to the owner for tax purposes. That version has a 25 percent tax rate, but with big caveats on how much of that income gets the preferential rate compared to the standard individual rate. The Senate version has a broader 23 percent deduction on pass-through income, albeit with a few guardrails to prevent wealthy individuals from gaming the system.

The House bill fully eliminates the individual and corporate alternative minimum tax, while the Senate reinstated both, but with a bigger individual exemption, as a last-minute revenue raiser, another potential pressure point.

The timing of various phase-outs for tax breaks would also need to be worked out. The House bill allows companies to fully write off the cost of certain equipment for only five years, while the Senate bill extends that period with a gradual phase out after 2022 a concession to holdout Sen. Jeff Flake. The Senate bill also phases out many individual tax breaks after 2025.

The Senate bill also effectively eliminates the Affordable Care Act s individual mandate while the House version does not, though the repeal has support from some House conservatives.

The bills are likely now to move to a conference committee to resolve differences between the two versions. Lawmakers have been adamant that they want to go to a conference, with House Speaker Paul Ryan tweeting a joke to that effect Saturday morning.

And in a sign that legislation isn t finished until the president puts pen to paper, there s now a new wrinkle in the conference process: Trump hinted Saturday that the hard-fought-for, permanent, 20 percent corporate rate in both tax bills may now be flexible.

It could be 22 when it comes out but it could also be 20, Trump said, according to a Saturday pool report. We ll see what ultimately comes out.

TECHNOLOGY

FBI Director Christopher Wray will testify Thursday before the House Judiciary Committee as part of a routine oversight hearing. Wray is likely to face questions regarding his agency s support for a clean reauthorization of Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, a provision that expires at the end of the month. The provision now gives the FBI the ability to access information incidentally collected on Americans without a warrant, and Congress is debating whether to curtail or entirely restrict that access. Wray is also a strong proponent of policies that would allow law enforcement officials to access the encrypted communications of suspected criminals, and may face questions on the encryption debate that periodically sweeps through Congress.

Sen. Elizabeth Warrennand Rep. David Cicilline are both slated to speak Wednesday at an event on monopolies hosted by liberal tech group Open Markets. Warren has frequently targeted Silicon Valley s top companies for criticism, arguing that firms like Facebook and Google operate like monopolies and make it impossible for competitors to enter the market. The senator (and possible 2020 Democratic presidential candidate) has recently begun making the case that big tech s top companies should be broken up to prevent further market abuses.

The House Oversight and Government Reform Subcommittee on Information Technology will meet Thursday for an oversight hearing into the Veterans Affairs Department's cybersecurity and IT systems. The House Committee on Science, Space and Technology will hold two hearings Wednesday, one into the review of the National Science Foundation s Innovation Corps and another into NASA s deployment of large telescopes.

WHITE HOUSE

Trump s week features a quiet three days in Washington bracketed by two potentially controversial trips out of town. He starts Monday with travel to Utah where he will announce plans to reduce the size of the Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante national monuments. The two monuments had been established by Democratic presidents under the 1906 Antiquities Act. On Friday, he will hold a campaign-style rally in Pensacola, Florida, only 60 miles from Alabama, site of a hotly contested Dec. 12 special Senate election. Midweek, he has a light schedule while in Washington, with a planned Cabinet meeting Wednesday and a Hanukkah reception Thursday.

urn:contentItem:5YBB-7681-DY4X-T00W-00000-00Outlook: Senate to consider sweeping energy package2020-03-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisOutlook: Senate to consider sweeping energy packageBrian Dabbs, Zach C. Cohen, Casey Wooten

The Senate kicks off several days of votes Monday on a sweeping, 555-page energy bill geared towards boosting emerging technologies such as carbon capture and advanced nuclear, and strengthening energy efficiency in buildings.

Sen. Lisa Murkowski, the term-limited chair of the Energy and Natural Resources Committee, is aiming for a big bipartisan vote. The package, which she and Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin introduced just last week, is a compilation of dozens of bills that passed out of the committee last year.

But that hope of bipartisan consensus is hindered by staunch opposition from environmental groups, who say the research-and-development section are insufficient to address climate change. Those groups, including the Sierra Club and Friends of the Earth, are also bashing sections designed to increase natural-gas exports and mining of metals such as uranium and lithium.

The amendment process for the legislation is expected to be rigorous and contentious. Democrats are likely to try to tack legislation onto the package to implement federal royalties for metal mining. Murkowski considers that measure a poison pill . Lawmakers are also aiming to add the Use It Act, which carves out $85 million to boost the Environmental Protection Agency support for carbon-capture technologies.

A play to put building-code language into the energy-efficiency section is likely to garner the most attention. Many Republicans oppose it, and Murkowski stripped that legislation from the bill passed out of committee. Democrats, meanwhile, say the language is critical to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions.

If the package passes the Senate, it faces an even more tenuous fate in the House, where environmental groups are already leaning on climate hawks to reject it. Democrats in the House are likely to use the legislation to push a suite of clean-energy tax credits, which are a divisive issue across both chambers.

Both chambers appropriations-subcommittee hearings roll on this week.

In the House, on Tuesday, the Agriculture and Financial Services and General Government Subcommittees will hold member days Tuesday. State, Foreign Operations and Related Programs meets on the United States Agency for International Development budget request on as well, while the Legislative Branch Subcommittee will hold a hearing on the House Officers Budget request.

The Interior, Environment and Related Agencies Subcommittee holds a hearing Wednesday on the Environmental Protection Agency s budget request, while the Financial Services subcommittee examines the Treasury Department s budget request as Secretary Steven Mnuchin comes to the Hill.

Six doctors from the National Institute of Health testify Wednesday for that agency s budget request before the Labor, Health and Human Services, Education and Related Agencies Subcommittee. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Ben Carson will testify on his department's budget request Wednesday, as will Veterans Affairs Secretary Robert Wilkie.

As for the Senate, Transportation Security Administrator David Pekoske is scheduled to appear before the Homeland Security Subcommittee on Tuesday.

The real action is Wednesday, when three Cabinet secretaries: Elaine Chao of Transportation, David Bernhardt of Interior, and Dan Brouillette of Energy testify before separate subcommittees. That day, Appropriations Chairman Richard Shelby will convene the Defense Subcommittee to hear from Pentagon officials on budget requests for the National Guard and Reserve.

Then on Thursday, appropriators will hear from Education Secretary Betsy DeVos and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross on their respective departments funding needs.

Lawmakers are set to vote this week on H.R. 1140, the Rights for Transportation Security Officers Act, which would grant Transportation Security Administration officers rights and protections equal to other federal workers.

Congress may also act to address the spread of the coronavirus as federal officials warn that the disease is almost certain to impact the country. Appropriators continue to negotiate on a multibillion-dollar top-line number, but House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer have already staked their flag on certain conditions. In a joint statement Thursday, they said supplemental measures must be entirely new funding earmarked for fighting the virus with strong provisions providing affordable vaccines to all that need it and assistance for impacted businesses and state and local governments.

While the Senate is not scheduled to confirm any nominees this week, the Senate Judiciary Committee is slated to hear from pending nominees   Wednesday .

Here s what else is on tap this week:

DEFENSE AND FOREIGN POLICY

The United States and the Taliban signed a peace agreement in Doha, Qatar on Saturday, setting in motion the withdrawal of U.S. forces from America s longest-running war. The agreement requires the U.S. to draw down to 8,600 troops in-country within 135 days, roughly the same level as when Trump took office, and fully withdraw by May 2021. The Taliban, in exchange, must break ties with al-Qaeda and other terrorist groups that could threaten the U.S. homeland.

The deal also sets up a prisoner swap of thousands of detainees on March 10, the same day that intra-Afghan talks are planned to begin. Those talks may eventually lead to a peace deal that could formally return the Taliban to the internationally recognized government.

Trump is likely to herald the agreement in his reelection campaign as proof of his ability to end America s military entanglements abroad.

No hearings have been scheduled on the deal, partly because of lawmakers busy schedule with 2021 budgeting.

Air Force Secretary Barbara Barrett kicks off the week Tuesday with testimony to the Senate Armed Services Committee. Later in the day, defense officials testify on U.S. military policy in the Arctic, and behind closed doors on the Pentagon s cyber operations.

Defense Secretary Mark Esper and Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Mark Milley testify to the committee Wednesday afternoon. Both faced sharp questions from House lawmakers last week about the diversion of funding to border construction, and the Navy s shipbuilding account.

Earlier that morning, lawmakers will examine vetting policies for international military students following the attack by Saudi trainees at Naval Air Station Pensacola, and Navy officials testify about shipbuilding. Acting Navy Secretary Thomas Modly and other top ranking Navy officials testify on Thursday.

The House Armed Services Committee has an equally rigorous schedule, with seven hearings scheduled.

Army Secretary Ryan McCarthy and Army Chief of Staff Gen. James McConville testify Tuesday on the 2021 budget. Later that afternoon, top Air Force officials speak on Space Force readiness, and National Nuclear Security Administration chief Lisa Gordon-Hagerty testifies on her agency's budget. The Navy s shipbuilding account was reportedly cut this year in order to boost nuclear-weapons spending.

On Wednesday, Barrett returns to Capitol Hill to brief the House Armed Services Committee, Navy officials testify on the aircraft and force-projection programs, and Gen. Paul Nakasone testifies on the U.S. Cyber Command budget.

The committee ends budget hearings Thursday with testimony from Army and Marine Corps officials on modernization programs.

The House Foreign Affairs Committee calls former U.S. government officials to testify Tuesday on the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. The committee marks legislation on Thursday that would reestablish an advisory council to Trump on global health, and mandate an all-of-government approach to global pandemics in light of the coronavirus outbreak.

Sen. Rob Portman presides Thursday over the only Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing scheduled for the week. The State Department s counter-propaganda chief Lea Gabrielle testifies on the global disinformation threat.

ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT

On top of the energy bill on the Senate floor, a slew of energy and environment hearings are taking place in both chambers.

Brouillette is heading to the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee on Tuesday to defend the White House budget for fiscal 2021. He ll likely get an earful from Democrats over White House aims to eliminate the Advanced Research Projects Agency-Energy, a program central to the development of next-generation energy technology.

The budget boosts funding for coal innovation and carbon capture, as well as nuclear. But the White House is reversing course on funding for the permanent nuclear-waste storage at Yucca Mountain, Nevada. No funds are carved out for that purpose.

The Energy Department is largely spared from the draconian budget cuts the Trump White House repeatedly proposes. The total budget for Energy is $35.4 billion, a roughly $3 billion decrease from enacted levels.

Environmental Protection Agency chief Andrew Wheeler is set to testify before a House Appropriations subcommittee Wednesday. Wheeler faced fierce resistance from House Democrats during testimony last week. The budget proposal provides $6.7 billion for the EPA, a higher request than past years but $2.3 billion below the current enacted level.

Meanwhile, Interior Secretary David Bernhardt is taking a pass this week. Instead, Susan Combs, assistant secretary for Policy, Management, and Budget at the Department of the Interior, will testify before the House Natural Resources Committee on Wednesday. Committee Chairman Raul Grijalva is threatening to subpoena the department over a Bureau of Land Management reorganization effort, as well as a discontinued study on mountaintop removal.

The White House is requesting $12.7 billion for the department, a 16 percent decrease from enacted levels.

The Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee is expected to approve Federal Energy Regulatory Commission General Counsel James Danly as a commissioner before the Brouillette hearing. That vote is expected to pass largely along party lines. The committee will also hold a hearing on long-term prospects for global energy markets Thursday.

And the House Energy and Commerce Committee will hold a hearing on Wednesday on plastic pollution. That issue has entered into the limelight in recent months. The Save Our Seas 2.0 measure passed the Senate in January. A far more aggressive bill, the   Break Free From Plastic Pollution Act of 2020 , is now introduced in both chambers.

HEALTH

The U.S. saw its first fatality from the novel coronavirus COVID-19 in Washington state over the weekend. This prompted a "Dear Colleague" letter from Pelosi, discussing plans to get emergency supplemental funding to the floor. Globally, the coronavirus has killed around 3,000 people and sickened more than 87,500.

The supplemental must also ensure that vaccines are affordable and available to all who need them, she wrote.

Lawmakers this week will participate in a slew of hearings focusing on the outbreak and the U.S. response. Senators on the Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee will hear from key health officials on the response to the coronavirus Tuesday. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Principal Deputy Director Anne Schuchat, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases Director Anthony Fauci, Health and Human Services Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response, Robert Kadlec and Food and Drug Administration Commissioner Stephen Hahn will testify.

This comes after the top Democrat on the committee, Sen. Patty Murray, wrote to Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar about reported disputes within HHS around the repatriation of American passengers infected with the disease from the Diamond Princess cruise ship. In the midst of this domestic and global public health emergency, it is critical that public health officials and their expertise guide any and all decisions about COVID-19 preparedness and response efforts, wrote Murray and Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee top Democrat Sen. Gary Peters.

On Wednesday, the Senate Commerce, Science, and Transportation Committee s Aviation and Space Subcommittee will have a hearing on the role of global air-transportation companies in mitigating the spread of the coronavirus. Witnesses will include the Transportation Department Acting Undersecretary for Policy Joel Szabat, CDC s National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases Director Nancy Messonnier, and Customs and Border Protection Acting Commissioner Mark Morgan.

The Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee on Thursday holds a hearing looking at the federal interagency response to the disease outbreak and the preparations for global pandemics. Witnesses include Ken Cuccinelli, the acting deputy secretary at the Homeland Security Department, and Robert Kadlec, assistant secretary for preparedness and response at HHS.

House committees will also hold more hearings on the coronavirus, including two on Wednesday. In the morning, the House Homeland Security Committee will have a hearing looking at a response to a pandemic threat. In the afternoon, the Oversight and Reform Committee s National Security Subcommittee will look at the biodefense and response to the outbreak.

On Thursday, the House Science, Space, and Technology Committee will have a hearing on understanding the spread of infectious diseases and using innovative solutions.

Lawmakers will also take on other public health issues this week. On Tuesday, the House Energy and Commerce Health Subcommittee meets for a hearing on proposals to help patients with substance use disorders. The committee will look proposals like allowing states to restart Medicaid coverage for incarcerated individuals up to 30 days before their release prison.

Officials from the National Institutes of Health, including Director Francis Collins, will be on Capitol Hill on Wednesday to discuss the department's 2021 budget request with the House appropriations subcommittee that oversees the HHS budget.

TAXES AND TRADE

There s a new national taxpayer advocate on the scene, with the Treasury Department and the IRS announcing last week that Erin Collins has taken on the role permanently. Nina Olson, who held the post for 18 years, retired in August. Collins comes to the job from KPMG and the IRS chief counsel s office.

Collins has spent the past two decades at one of the most prominent accounting firms in the country, so I d particularly like to discuss her priorities for improving IRS customer service for working folks, Sen. Ron Wyden, the top Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee, said in a statement.

The House Ways and Means Committee meets Tuesday morning for a hearing on the 2021 budget request with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. The following day, the Subcommittee on Select Revenue Measures gathers in the morning for a hearing to examine the impact of the tax code on Native American tribes.

The Senate Finance Subcommittee on International Trade, Customs, and Global Competitiveness, meanwhile, holds a hearing Tuesday on censorship as a nontariff barrier to trade. The lineup of witnesses includes actor Richard Gere, the chairman of the International Campaign for Tibet, as well as legal and think tank experts.

The United Kingdom is set to publish its formal negotiating objectives for a U.S. trade deal this week. U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, who met with his British counterpart, Liz Truss, in London last week, will speak on Monday evening at the Oxford Union, giving him a chance to immediately react to the UK's trade position if it's released on Monday as expected.

TECHNOLOGY

With just two weeks to go before three key provisions of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act expire, Congress is stuck on a way forward. December s revelation that the FISA court failed to prevent the FBI from improperly surveilling a Trump 2016 campaign associate sparked bipartisan calls for reforming the law, but lawmakers have struggled to reach consensus on how far to take those reforms.

Last week, the House Judiciary Committee abruptly cancelled the markup of a Senate bill that would end the National Security Agency s controversial (and currently inactive) call detail records program. Progressive Democrats, led by Rep. Zoe Lofgren, objected to the markup without the inclusion of additional reforms. Some Republicans have also called for more far-reaching changes to FISA, despite voiced preferences by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Attorney General Bill Barr that FISA receive a clean reauthorization.

If lawmakers can t come to a consensus in time, they may move to temporarily reauthorize the three FISA provisions to provide breathing room for reform efforts. Senate Majority Whip John Thune hinted at such a move late last week.

The Senate Commerce Committee will hear from Huawei s two chief international competitors on Wednesday, as lawmakers look for ways to provide America s foreign allies with economical alternatives to the Chinese telecommunications giant. Scandinavian telecommunications firms Nokia and Ericsson are slated to testify regarding the security and integrity of the international telecommunications supply chain.

The Senate Finance Subcommittee on International Trade, Customs, and Global Competitiveness will hold a hearing Tuesday on censorship as a nontariff barrier to trade. The hearing is likely to focus heavily on how the Great Firewall of China Beijing s efforts to censor the internet for its citizens acts as a trade barrier for U.S. companies, particularly in the technology space.

The House Small Business Committee is holding back-to-back hearings focused on tech policy. On Tuesday, lawmakers will hear testimony from industry and legal experts on how the Supreme Court s 2018 South Dakota v. Wayfair decision which allows a state to collect online sales taxes from businesses who do not have a brick-and-mortar location within its borders has impacted small businesses. On Wednesday, lawmakers will discuss the benefits of blockchain technology for small businesses with a panel of technology experts.

The House Commerce Subcommittee on Consumer Protection and Commerce meets Wednesday for a hearing examining a variety of fake or unsafe products being sold on online marketplaces, as well as potential policy solutions.

Apple and TikTok are once again snubbing an invitation from Sen. Josh Hawley to testify regarding their ties to the Chinese government. As chairman of the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Crime and Terrorism, Hawley is holding a hearing Wednesday on what he calls two dangerous partners: big tech and Beijing. The senator has previously argued that TikTok s ownership by a Chinese company, and Apple s storage of user data in China, both represent threats to the data and privacy of American citizens. Hawley introduced a bill that would ban the transfer or storage of user data and encryption keys within Chinese borders.

WHITE HOUSE

Trump s week is heavy with politics.

On Monday, after meeting with the representatives of pharmaceutical companies in the afternoon, he goes to Charlotte for a political rally before North Carolina votes on Super Tuesday. On Tuesday, he will address the National Association of Counties Legislative Conference and travel to Bethesda, Maryland to visit the National Institutes of Health. On Wednesday, he will address the Hispanic business group the Latino Coalition Legislative Conference. On Thursday, he goes to Scranton, Pennsylvania, to participate in a live Fox News town hall. On Friday, he s off to Palm Beach, Florida to meet with supporters and raise campaign money.

urn:contentItem:5SJ0-DX21-JBNW-3378-00000-00Outlook: Senate to Take Up Defense Bill as Trump Meets Kim2018-06-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisOutlook: Senate to Take Up Defense Bill as Trump Meets KimMackenzie Weinger

The Senate is poised to take up the massive $716 billion National Defense Authorization Act this week, and lawmakers could use the must-pass bill to try to challenge some of President Trump s national security policies.

A number of proposals are up for possible consideration, including an amendment that seeks to override Trump s controversial deal to ease penalties on ZTE. Top intelligence officials and many lawmakers have warned that the Chinese telecommunications firm's products pose a threat to national security. The provision would spike the Trump administration's agreement and reimpose penalties on ZTE, which has repeatedly violated U.S. sanctions.

Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Bob Corker, meanwhile, has unveiled legislation that would limit the president s ability to impose tariffs for national security reasons, requiring congressional approval before they go into effect. Trump has invoked a national security provision to slap tariffs on steel and aluminum exported by Canada, Mexico, and the European Union, sparking retaliatory tariffs on a variety of American goods. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said last week he won t call Corker's measure up as a freestanding bill, so it may be offered as an amendment to the NDAA.

Other potential amendments lawmakers have submitted include provisions to prohibit selling F-35 joint strike fighters to Turkey until specific conditions are met and to help states bolster their election security, among others. It s not clear yet what amendments may go ahead, and there could be procedural delays. After the NDAA passes the Senate, it will have to be reconciled with the House version and the wrangling that takes place behind closed doors can go on for months.

The early part of this week will also be dominated by news out of Singapore, where Trump will meet North Korea s Kim Jong-un. The summit is scheduled to take place at 9 a.m. local time on Tuesday 9 p.m. Monday on the East Coast.

I think I'm very well prepared, Trump said last week. I don't think I have to prepare very much. It's about attitude; it's about willingness to get things done.

Here s what else is on tap this week:

DEFENSE AND FOREIGN POLICY

The Senate is scheduled to vote Monday evening to open debate on the NDAA for fiscal 2019 after voting 92-4 to proceed last Thursday.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee is set to consider six nominees this week: Kimberly Breier to be the assistant secretary of State for Western Hemisphere Affairs; Kenneth George to be the ambassador to Uruguay; Joseph Mondello to be the ambassador to Trinidad and Tobago; Harry Harris to be the ambassador to South Korea; Tibor Nagy to be assistant secretary of State for African Affairs; and David Schenker to be assistant secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs.

The House Armed Services Tactical Air and Land Forces Subcommittee will hold a hearing Wednesday on the Defense Department's aviation-mishap review and oversight process, while the Readiness Subcommittee will meet for a hearing Thursday on Navy and Air Force depot policy issues and infrastructure concerns.

The House Foreign Affairs Middle East and North Africa Subcommittee is scheduled to have a hearing Wednesday on resources in the region with officials from the State Department and U.S. Agency for International Development. The full committee will gather Thursday for a hearing on democracy promotion with outside experts.

ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT

Environmental policy is likely to grind a bipartisan appropriations push in the Senate to a halt this week, at least temporarily. An Appropriations Committee subpanel will mark up fiscal 2019 spending legislation for the Environmental Protection Agency and the Interior Department on Tuesday, and the full committee will likely mark up the EPA and Interior bill later in the week. That legislation is notoriously divisive.

In recent years, Republicans have tacked riders onto the legislation to address wide-ranging EPA and Interior policy, such as carbon emissions and Endangered Species Act regulations. The House Appropriations Committee passed an EPA and Interior bill last week along party lines. Even Rep. Henry Cuellar, a moderate Democrat who often sides with Republicans on environmental policy, opposed the bill.

Democrats criticized the legislation s $100 million cut to the EPA budget, a figure well short of the White House call to cut the agency budget by more than $2 billion. The legislation also includes a set of riders, including controversial language to repeal the EPA s Clean Water Rule, which Administrator Scott Pruitt is aiming to trash and replace in the coming months.

Senate Republicans haven t released their EPA and Interior bill publicly ahead of the markup. The Senate Appropriations Committee has approved a range of appropriations bills with overwhelming bipartisan support in recent weeks.

Also on Tuesday, all five members of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission will testify before the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee. Expect lawmakers to grill the FERC commissioners over a recent White House directive to devise a plan to bail out financially embattled coal and nuclear plants. The Energy Department is now charged with that task, but FERC, an independent commission that regulates energy markets, would presumably play a role.

Meanwhile, a House Energy and Commerce subpanel will hold a hearing Thursday on anti-terrorism safeguards at chemical facilities. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives concluded that a deliberate fire sparked a 2013 explosion at a West, Texas chemical facility that killed 15 people.

HEALTH

President Trump s Department of Justice has decided it will not defend key portions of the Affordable Care Act from a lawsuit that aims to knock down the law. The DOJ targets provisions that guarantee coverage for everyone, regardless of health status, and the limitations on how much insurance companies can vary premiums based on health status, gender, and age.

In a brief filed last week, the DOJ asked the court to enter a declaratory judgment that the ACA s provisions containing the individual mandate as well as the guaranteed issue and community-rating requirements will all be invalid beginning on January 1, 2019.

On Capitol Hill, the House is expected to start considering legislation to address the opioid epidemic.

This month, the House is poised to pass meaningful reforms that collectively can make a real difference in our communities. These bills will bolster enforcement efforts to protect our communities, advance prevention and public health efforts, and address coverage and payment issues within Medicare and Medicaid, House Energy and Commerce Chairman Greg Walden and Health Subcommittee Chairman Michael Burgess wrote in an op-ed for Fox News on Wednesday.

On the other side of Congress, the Senate Finance Committee will hold an executive session on its legislation to address opioid addiction in Medicare and Medicaid, the Helping to End Addiction and Lessen Substance Use Disorders Act of 2018.

The Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee will examine Trump s drug-pricing blueprint on Tuesday, and Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar will testify.

TAXES

Summer is in full tilt on Capitol Hill. Congress celebrated seersucker Thursday last week, lawmakers are preparing for their midterm fights, and the Senate is realizing it has way more on its plate than it has time to clear by November.

So when will tax writers find the time to cross off items on their growing To-Do list?

McConnell announced last week that the upper chamber would be working through most of August. Much of that time will be devoted to appropriations bills and confirming judicial nominees.

Theoretically, though, that expanded schedule could be used to take up two items important to tax world: confirming IRS commissioner nominee Charles Rettig and advancing the House-passed bill overhauling the IRS administration. Lawmakers haven t yet given any timeline for those items yet, though Senate Finance Committee Chairman Orrin Hatch has said he d like to hold a hearing on Rettig s nomination soon.

Before that, however, Hatch s committee will hold a hearing this Tuesday on the nomination of several tax-court judges and for Jeffrey Kessler to be assistant secretary of Commerce for enforcement and compliance.

Kessler s hearing will be particularly topical, given Trump s recent, awkward visit to the G7 conference in Canada and the diplomatic turmoil surrounding the steel and aluminum tariffs imposed on key U.S. trade partners. The Enforcement and Compliance   division monitors steel imports and compliance with trade agreements and antidumping rules.

In the House, Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady told reporters Wednesday that he hopes to have a set of technical corrections to last year s tax-overhaul bill by the end of the year. Industry, however, would like them sooner.

About 100 retail and restaurant companies sent a letter last week to tax writers asking them to fix what they are dubbing the retail glitch, a name taken from the recently fixed grain glitch in the tax bill. The retail glitch is a drafting error that causes improvements to retail and restaurants to be written off over as much as 39 years rather than the one year intended by lawmakers.

But the clock is ticking to advance corrections legislation, at least before the November midterms. There are only a few vehicles on which a technical-corrections bill can ride. The Federal Aviation Administration reauthorization bill remains the top target, but Sen. John Thune, who helms the committee with jurisdiction over the agency, says he doesn't want extraneous tax riders attached to that bill. Industry may have to wait for the lame-duck session before seeing any legislative fixes.

TECHNOLOGY

As the Senate takes up the must-pass NDAA this week, top Chinese telecommunications firms ZTE and Huawei could be caught in the middle of the debate.

Last week, a bipartisan group of senators inserted language into the NDAA that would restore crippling Commerce Department penalties against ZTE should the White House move forward with plans to grant the company a reprieve. ZTE was found to have violated U.S. government restrictions against trading with North Korea and Iran, and along with Huawei its U.S. operations are seen as an acute national security threat by many lawmakers and intelligence officials.

A majority of senators appear ready to back language blocking the White House s reprieve for ZTE. But some senators are not on board including Intelligence Committee Chairman Richard Burr, who told National Journal last week that he s opposed to tying Trump s hands as he tries to maneuver through complicated trade issues with China. And several top House Republicans are already expressing their opposition to the measure, raising the prospect that the provision could be stripped from the NDAA during conference even if it does pass the Senate.

The Federal Communications Commission s net-neutrality rules officially expire on June 11, marking the end of federal regulations that prevented internet service providers from blocking, slowing down, or prioritizing certain types of web traffic. The Republican-led FCC voted to overturn those rules in December, but they won t be officially taken out of the Federal Register until Monday.

The expiration of the old net-neutrality rules comes as the House continues to debate a Congressional Review Act resolution that would overturn the Republican FCC s order to rescind the earlier rules. Experts say that most internet service providers will hesitate to alter the way they prioritize web traffic or price their services until that debate has concluded. FCC Chairman Ajit Pai will address the issue during a Thursday appearance at the Cato Institute, a libertarian think tank.

Lawmakers continue to debate the pros and cons of tougher disclosure regulations for digital advertisements months after the introduction of the Honest Ads Act. On Thursday, the House Energy and Commerce Digital Commerce and Consumer Protection Subcommittee will hold a hearing to map out the contours of the digital advertising ecosystem. Digital ads came under intense fire last year for the role they played in allowing Russian-backed actors to clandestinely influence American social-media users during the 2016 presidential election.

The Senate Judiciary Committee is also taking another look at how to stop foreign actors from interfering in U.S. elections. On Tuesday, the committee will hold a hearing on how best to ensure that law enforcement is equipped to target those seeking to undermine the democratic process in the United States.

The Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee will mark up several bills on Wednesday, including the Cyber Safety Act. That bill would clarify protections and responsibilities related to cybersecurity under the Homeland Security Act.

The Senate Commerce Committee will hold a hearing Wednesday with David Redl, the head of the National Telecommunications and Information Administration. The NTIA is in charge of managing the government s spectrum, which is in high demand by private actors seeking to grow their own network coverage in parts of the country.

The long-running court battle over the proposed merger of AT&T and Time Warner will come to a close on Tuesday, and the decision could have tremendous implications for tech mergers down the line. The DOJ Antitrust Division unexpectedly challenged the vertical merger last year, arguing that the combination of AT&T's telecommunications infrastructure with Time Warner's content could hurt consumers and unfairly disadvantage media competitors. By Tuesday, U.S. District Judge Richard Leon is expected to decide whether to back the government's argument or allow the merger to proceed.

The DOJ's decision to go after the merger was a controversial one. Vertical mergers are typically approved by antitrust regulators, and Trump's animus towards CNN, a Time Warner subsidiary, led some to suspect the White House pressured antitrust head Makan Delrahim to target the company as payback. Experts have speculated that a finding in favor of AT&T and Time Warner may lead to an explosion in big tech and media mergers, with major companies in Silicon Valley and elsewhere seeing a green light to acquire new firms.

WHITE HOUSE

President Trump's week will be dominated by his time in Singapore and his historic meeting with North Korean dictator Kim Jong-un. The White House has said little about the rest of the week, giving the president flexibility on his stay in Singapore.

urn:contentItem:5TW9-GKD1-JBNW-329K-00000-00Outlook: Shutdown Deadline Likely Delayed Due to Bush Memorial2018-12-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisOutlook: Shutdown Deadline Likely Delayed Due to Bush MemorialZach C. Cohen, Daniel Newhauser

The death of George H.W. Bush will pause a mourning Washington this week as the District prepares for funeral proceedings. The 41st president will lie in state Monday through Wednesday in the Capitol rotunda.

The National Cathedral will then hold a memorial service before Bush's body is sent to Texas to be honored and buried. President Trump said Saturday he would absolutely consider and probably agree to a one- or two-week continuing resolution for Friday s deadline to fund the Homeland Security Department and other agencies that are at risk of shutting down.

The parties spent the last week trading blame for the possibility of a shutdown, as Trump dug in his heels on demands for $5 billion in funding for a border wall, rather than the $1.6 billion for border security included in the bipartisan Senate version of a bill funding DHS. Senate Appropriations Committee Chairman Richard Shelby floated a plan last week to increase the border-related spending to $2.5 billion, while Minority Leader Chuck Schumer suggested a yearlong continuing resolution covering the DHS to avoid a shutdown.

It also remains to be seen whether a compromise farm bill will be able to withstand opposition from House conservatives, who objected to the removal of language that would have instituted tougher work requirements on some food-stamp recipients. Senate Agriculture Chairman Pat Roberts expressed optimism that the deal would pass the Senate. A reauthorization of the nation's flood-insurance program, which was expended on a short-term basis two weeks ago, is also expected to be included in a year-end package.

Following the waning support for Thomas Farr s nomination to the District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina, the Senate will take up the nomination of Bernard McNamee to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. Final votes on the nominations of Jonathan Kobes to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit and Kathleen Kraninger to a five-year term as director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will follow. Senators will also continue to weigh in on a new farm-bill agreement, a trade deal with Mexico and Canada, and a resolution condemning American involvement in the war in Yemen.

Here s what else is on tap this week:

DEFENSE AND FOREIGN POLICY

The Senate voted 63-37 last week to advance a resolution that would end U.S. military support for the Saudi-led war effort in Yemen, reflecting unease and frustration over the Trump administration s response to both the crisis and the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi at a Saudi consulate. Senators could vote to approve the measure this week, but House Republican leaders have already blocked action on a similar resolution.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has a packed schedule this Tuesday. In the morning and afternoon, members will consider several ambassador nominations. That morning, the East Asia, the Pacific, and International Cybersecurity Policy Subcommittee also meets for a hearing on China with officials from the State Department and the U.S. Agency for International Development testifying.

On Wednesday, the Africa and Global Health Policy Subcommittee will hear testimony on Zimbabwe from Matthew Harrington, deputy assistant secretary of State in the Bureau of African Affairs, and from outside experts. Outgoing Sen. Jeff Flake, the subcommittee chair, has long-standing ties to Zimbabwe and served as an official elections observer in the country this summer following the end of Robert Mugabe s 37-year grip on power.

The Senate Armed Services Committee will meet Tuesday morning to consider Lt. Gen. Kenneth McKenzie Jr. to take over U.S. Central Command and Lt. Gen. Richard Clarke to be commander of U.S. Special Operations Command. On Wednesday afternoon, the Seapower and Readiness and Management Support Subcommittees will hear testimony from key officials on Navy and Marine Corps readiness.

The House Armed Services Emerging Threats and Capabilities Subcommittee meets Wednesday morning on the Defense Department s artificial-intelligence structure, investments, and applications. Lisa Porter, deputy Defense undersecretary for research and engineering, and Dana Deasy, the DoD s chief information officer, will testify. The following morning, the full committee meets to hear from the National Defense Strategy Commission.

HASC s Readiness and Seapower and Projection Forces Subcommittees will hold a hearing Thursday afternoon on whether Naval surface forces are on the road to recovery, with testimony from Adm. John Aquilino, commander of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, and Adm. Christopher Grady, commander of U.S. Fleet Forces Command.

And the House Foreign Affairs Africa, Global Health, Global Human Rights, and International Organizations Subcommittee on Wednesday will hold a hearing on international child abductions.

ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT

The House Energy and Commerce Environment Subcommittee will make a last-ditch effort this week to push legislation that would overhaul an ethanol-blending mandate known as the Renewable Fuel Standard.

Subpanel chairman John Shimkus released draft legislation in mid-November to sunset the corn-based ethanol mandate in 2023 but require vehicle manufacturers to sell cars with a higher octane level, which is typically achieved through ethanol blending. Shimkus will hold a hearing on the bill this Wednesday. Witnesses have not yet been announced. Ethanol producers have already vociferously denounced the legislation.

On the Senate side of the Capitol, the Energy and Natural Resources Committee will hold a sprawling markup Wednesday on nearly two dozen land-management and energy bills. Most of the bills are parochial and noncontroversial, and they could ride alongside a package that includes Land and Water Conservation Fund reauthorization at the end of this year or early next year.

Lawmakers in both chambers will also have to button up appropriations negotiations this week on the controversial Environmental Protection Agency and Interior Department account. The continuing resolution expires Dec. 7, and senators on both sides of the aisle are pushing House Republicans to trash a list of environmental riders on Endangered Species Act designations and emissions regulations, among other policy.

HEALTH

Sen. Chuck Grassley is still pushing to get a prison and sentencing-reform bill through Congress during the lame-duck. The legislation, which is still under discussion, includes provisions that would have some impact on substance-abuse disorders in the federal prison population.

Inmates would be able to participate in activities, including a substance-abuse program, to earn phone and visitation privileges along with time credit. The legislation would also require the Bureau of Prisons to evaluate and submit a plan to expand the pilot program that provides medication-assisted treatment for heroin and opioid abuse.

On the House side, the Energy and Commerce Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee will hold a hearing Wednesday on the availability of Sexual Assault Forensic Exams and sexual-assault nurse examiners at hospitals. Only 15 percent of hospitals in the U.S. provide SAFE kits, according to data from the International Association of Forensic Nurses.

The House Oversight and Government Reform Health Care and Government Operations Subcommittees will look at alternatives to fetal-tissue research in a hearing Thursday. The Health and Human Services Department launched a review in September of all research involving fetal tissue in light of the serious regulatory, moral, and ethical considerations involved.

TAXES

House Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady s year-end tax package got off to a rough start when leadership pulled a procedural vote on the measure set for Friday morning over intraparty disagreements.

Even if Brady can iron out the differences within his party, the bill still faces an uncertain future in the Senate, where the 60-vote threshold means supporters will have to get at least nine Democrats on board. The package has technical corrections to last year s tax-code overhaul, and Democrats had planned on extracting changes to the $1.5 trillion tax law in exchange for supporting the corrections. The tax package doesn t give them that opportunity with some of the most noncontroversial corrections.

Though the package is written so that it can get through the Senate with a single cloture vote, avoiding up to 30 hours of debate, the chamber has a packed schedule in the lame-duck session. Brady said last Tuesday that he s talking with Senate Democrats about moving the legislation.

As of Friday, it was unclear when House Republicans would try again to move the tax package.

The measure is likely the final tax bill Brady will shepherd before he steps down from his chairmanship to make way for Democrat Richard Neal in January.

On Tuesday, the Senate Finance Committee is set to hold a hearing on the nomination of Courtney Dunbar Jones to the U.S. Tax Court, where she would serve a 15-year term.

TECHNOLOGY

Mark Zuckerberg can breathe a temporary sigh of relief this week, as the spotlight on Capitol Hill turns to Google chief executive Sundar Pichai instead. Lawmakers on the House Judiciary Committee will question Pichai on Wednesday in a stated bid to examine the data collection, use and filtering practices of the tech platform. That likely means a reprise of GOP complaints that Google as well as its rivals Facebook and Twitter has shown a bias against conservative content hosted on its platform.

But other areas of concern are also set to be addressed. During a September hearing with Facebook and Twitter executives that Google failed to attend, several lawmakers brought up the search engine s plans to expand into China. Dubbed Project Dragonfly, the proposal has drawn the ire of members of Congress and many Google employees for showing a willingness on the company's part to kowtow to the Chinese government s strict online-censorship requirements. And as debate grinds on over a rework of federal antitrust theory to accommodate companies that traffic in reams of consumer data, Democrats are also likely to address Google s dominant market position.

It s been down and out several times over the past year, but the Senate s driverless-car bill simply refuses to die. In what has to be its last chance at passage this cycle, Commerce Committee Chairman John Thune told National Journal that supporters are looking to tack the AV Start Act onto the must-pass spending legislation being debated this week. We re really close with the trial lawyers, he said, suggesting that their recalcitrance is the reason why the bill remains stalled.

But, Thune added, senators would still need to hammer out some changes between AV Start and its companion bill in the House. He said discussions with the lower chamber have already started. We ll see, he said. It s a long way to the finish line, but at least we are making forward progress still.

The Senate Judiciary Committee will hold a two-panel hearing Wednesday on China s non-traditional espionage against the United States a likely nod to Beijing s theft of intellectual property and rumors of a backdoor for eavesdropping built into Chinese telecommunications equipment now plugged into the grids of the U.S. and allied nations. Lawmakers will hear from top officials at DHS, the Justice Department, and the FBI, as well as academic experts.

Oral arguments for the DOJ's appeal of the AT&T-Time Warner case are scheduled to begin on Thursday. Earlier this year, a U.S. District Court found that the media mega-merger could go forward, despite the DOJ's moves to block the transaction. The government s appeal is widely considered a long shot.

The House Judiciary Regulatory Reform, Commercial and Antitrust Law Subcommittee will meet Tuesday to hear from Federal Trade Commission chief Joseph Simons and DOJ antitrust head Makan Delrahim about the state of antitrust enforcement. Big tech s market share and its impact on consumers are always a focus of these hearings, and Tuesday is unlikely to be an exception.

The House Energy and Commerce Communications and Technology Subcommittee meets Thursday to examine the impact of the Ray Baum s Act, a package of bipartisan telecommunications bills that was signed into law earlier this year.

WHITE HOUSE

Back from the G-20 summit in Argentina, President Trump will attend the funeral services for George H.W. Bush on Wednesday at the National Cathedral. On Tuesday, he also is expected to meet with the Democratic leaders of Congress: Nancy Pelosi, the expected next speaker of the House; and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer.

urn:contentItem:5T93-YFP1-JCB7-100G-00000-00Out of sight, out of mind, out of luck2018-09-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. P4AOut of sight, out of mind, out of luckPatricia Ford

In a zero-attention-span society, even the most important issues slip out of mind when they drop from the headlines or get bumped from cable news. It's happening right now with net neutrality - a critical issue that affects everyone who uses the internet that seems to have fallen off the face of the earth.

Last December, the Trump administration repealed President Obama's net neutrality rules, setting off a firestorm of media attention and - if only briefly - focusing national attention on the need for clear rules ensuring that no internet company can block unpopular websites or unaffiliated services or otherwise discriminate online.

There was then a brief effort to revive the rules through a highly partisan longshot approach called the "CRA that made some headway in the Senate but was always, as its sponsors knew too well, dead on arrival in the House of Representatives.

While well-intentioned, it's no surprise this CRA tactic could not gain a foothold. It fetishized an anachronistic "public utility approach to net neutrality that many regarded as gratuitous overkill for a largely unregulated internet and a buzzkill for new investment. It also oddly paid worship to administrative regulations that change with every new administration rather than a permanent congressional law. Even if it had succeeded, the Trump FCC could have altered them again. It's kind of like that game of infinite regression.

In the meantime, the news cycle has churned on, and net neutrality is like a forgotten summer romance. Many have started to believe it was all hype, drummed up by the professional-consultant class to burnish their brands and raise funds, as the internet providers themselves have pledged to live by the rules even in their absence. Making sure they do now falls to the FTC as the honesty-in-advertising cop on the beat.

As much as we should celebrate consensus - and there seems to be widespread agreement on net neutrality now - legislation still seems to be the obvious coda. Legislation is a kind of "trust but verify insurance policy against a future provider that may want to, say, favor its new streaming service over those of, say, Netflix or Disney. But there are other reasons, too - interfering with internet traffic to increase profits is not just a salon-dinner theoretical conversation about future misbehavior by internet providers, it's a current day way-of-life for the internet's new gilded monopolies, like Facebook and Google.

Those companies that collect and profile our data and decide what we can see and where we can go online pose a greater risk of censorship and manipulation of our data than anyone. Washington's big thinkers in technology have come to the party late - after months of front-page stories of how these companies facilitate election interference, hate, and civic chaos and marketplace tyranny that is strip-mining our news, retail and creative industries.

Many of these leaders are now demanding that that net neutrality cover these Big Tech monopolies, as well as internet providers - something only a new law from Congress can effectively ensure. It would seem obvious to anyone watching the disintegration of the internet that there is a crisis too big to corporate promises or overworked regulators. Net neutrality for all goes to the basic ability of citizens to connect and communicate, to find meaningful information, to organize and participate in the political process in a fair and open way.

On a bipartisan basis, congressional inaction conjures images of Nero fiddling while the internet burns. There is little disagreement about net neutrality widely applied and little disagreement about reining in abuses that led to the Russia scandal, among others. It's up to party leadership on both sides to prove, contrary to growing populist sentiment in both camps, that they are not made up of decaying old politicians but rather modern problem solvers up to the task of protecting the most important communications medium of our time.

Poll after poll shows that this is what the public wants by large margins. But the permanent Washington set has been more interested in trying to leverage these poll numbers to make political hay. But that's the politics of cynicism that only fuels resentment of Washington and the spoilation of the internet.

There is a huge middle ground available here and a real opportunity for the kind of common-sense problem solving Americans routinely tell pollsters that they want. It'll only happen if we drop the political jawboning and get on with the peoples' business.

urn:contentItem:4T7X-F900-TX2J-G1DJ-00000-00Out-of-state deals stymie chance to build N.E. pillars2008-08-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. G1Out-of-state deals stymie chance to build N.E. pillarsScott Kirsner

Innovation Economy

Maybe I'm a glass-half-empty sort. Maybe I refuse to acknowledge the reality of the financial markets, and the need for entrepreneurs to deliver a return for their investors within a reasonable time.

But I can't help feeling that, whenever a New England company is sold to an out-of-state acquirer for big bucks, we've missed another chance to build a "pillar" company of our own.

When Dell Inc.pays $1.4 billion in cash for New Hampshire's EqualLogic Inc.this year after the storage start-up had filed to go public, it feels as if we've missed the opportunity to cultivate another EMC Corp.in our backyard. When VeriSign Inc.buys m-Qube Inc., one of the pioneers of content delivery to cellphones, for $250 million, that's a potentially significant anchor tenant we've lost for the mobile software community here. When Microsoft Corp.buys Softricity Inc., that's a pioneer in application virtualization - delivering software over a network connection - no longer seen as a leading player in the field, and headquartered right here in Boston to boot.

Let me present the glass-half-full case first. Acquisitions make a lot of money for founders and venture capitalists, who can then fly off and pollinate new companies. Most of the management team of m-Qube is now running other local start-ups like Matchmine, Turbine Entertainment, and Quattro Wireless. Former chief executive Jeff Glass is now an investor at Bain Capital Ventures in Boston.

Thanks to a decade of fairly steady acquisitions by non-New England purchases, our region is now home to outposts of most major technology companies, from Google to Microsoftto IBM to Oracle. Even cities like Atlanta, Chicago, or Austin don't have such a concentrated cluster of branch offices.

In some cases, an acquirer will keep growing the group it acquired. Dell is looking to hire more than 50 people at EqualLogic's old headquarters, mostly in engineering. Two of the company's three founders are still there, but chief executive Don Bulens left in June.

At a time when the stock market's interest in new offerings seems to have died, it's good to be producing companies someone wants to buy. Just last week, Hewlett-Packard Co.bought Colubris Networks of Waltham for an undisclosed sum. (I'm told by someone involved with the deal, but not authorized to talk about it, that the purchase price was only a bit more than the $50 million that had been invested in the company.)

And taking a company public is expensive. Charley Lax, one of the venture capitalists who put money into Colubris, says that "it costs us $4 million to take a company public because of Sarbanes-Oxley regulations, which create all sorts of additional paperwork. What company can afford that if their revenues are $40- or $50-million?" GlassHouse Technologies, another of the companies in the portfolio of Grand Banks Capital, Lax's Newton firm, filed to go public last December but hasn't done so yet. Based in Framingham, GlassHouse earned $40 million in the first nine months of 2007, selling services and technology to help customers manage their data centers.

Now, my glass-half-empty case.

Having a branch office is not the same thing as having a pillar company. Pillar companies like Google, Apple, and Intel pull smart people to Silicon Valley from all over the world and attract media attention. Companies that have been bought by out-of-state acquirers, like Monster.com or TripAdvisor (both Massachusetts sites owned by New York parents), often complain to me that no one remembers they're based here.

By not cultivating our own big companies - this seems obvious - we don't have a big pool of executives who have experience running big companies. "As you're looking for CEOs to run midstage or later-stage companies, what you don't have here is the executive-level talent who have the experience running significant enterprises, beyond EMC," says Lou Volpe of Kodiak Venture Partners, a Waltham firm. "That's because all the big tech companies are on the West Coast."

In 2006, Kodiak sold one of its companies, IMlogic, to Symantec Corp., a Silicon Valley security company. It was a good deal for everyone involved: roughly $100 million, all cash. At the time, IMlogic was earning about $10 million a year. But IMlogic's chief executive, Francis deSouza, is now a senior vice president at Symantec's California headquarters, and a few months after the IMlogic acquisition, Symantec laid off 71 people at its Waltham office, according to press reports.

I know that locally run companies can lay off people, too - but somehow job cuts always feel worse when done by remote control.

Innovative products created can vanish, or become less competitive, once they're absorbed within a big company. In March 2006, Microsoftbought a promising Cambridge start-up called Onfolio, which made software for managing links and information collected during Web research, and moved the team of six people out to Redmond, Wash. Two years later, Onfolio users were posting messages on Microsoft'sOnfolio site with headlines like "Onfolio is dead." One user commented, "A nice example on how to destroy value. Microsoftacquired it and haven't updated since." (Founder J.J. Allaire left Microsoftlast fall and returned to Boston.)

"There's a culture here in Boston where low-profile success is expected and high-profile success is not," says Paul Deninger, the vice chairman of the investment bank Jefferies & Co., observing that the "accumulation of great wealth" and larger-than-life entrepreneurial personalities seem to go against New England's puritanical grain. (Deninger sold his local firm to New York's Jefferies in 2003.)

"You need not just financial drive to go public, but emotional drive," says former m-Qube chief executive Glass. "You have to want to be a stand-alone, lasting, self-sustaining company." The team at m-Qube had talked about going public, but concluded that their company wasn't yet mature enough.

A123 Systems, a Watertown developer of next-generation batteries, seems to have the drive. They filed earlier this month to raise $175 million in the public markets.

But with every substantial company that gets bought, I wonder what might've been.

EqualLogicchief executive Don Bulens had bought his ticket to go to New York last November. On Tuesday, Nov. 6, he planned to run training sessions for the sales forces at Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse, and then start meeting with potential investors.

But on Monday, EqualLogicgot bought. It was the biggest all-cash acquisition of a venture capital funded start-up, ever.

We should all be happy, right?

urn:contentItem:600V-7T51-JBJN-M1RJ-00000-00Outraged with Twitter, Trump threatens to "close" social media2020-05-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:15:48ZLexisNexisOutraged with Twitter, Trump threatens to "close" social media


U.S. President Donald Trump said he will "regulate" or even "close" social media if they "silence" conservative voices, hours after Twitter first included a warning that called into question the veracity of a message from the representative.


The platform denies Trump's mail-in voting messages.
Facebook promotes social polarization, says WSJ
"Republicans believe that social media platforms completely silence conservative voices. We will regulate them tightly or close them before we let something like this happen," he added, considering that as early as 2016 these networks tried - "and failed" - with something similar.
"We can't let a more sophisticated version happen again," he warned.
Trump said mail-in voting, "a free reindly for deception, forgery and ballot theft, nor can it be allowed. With this system, the representative said, "the one who deceives the most will win."
After accusing tech giants of 'silencing conservative voices,'" Trump added, "We will regulate them vigorously or close them before we allow that to happen.'"
Trump responded this way after Twitter added a misleading content alert notice to two tweets from the president, who argued that mail ballots were 'fraudulent'' and that "mailboxes will be stolen,' among other things.
Below the tweets, Twitter placed a link that reads, "Get the facts about vote by mail'' that guides users to a Twitter 'Moments' page with verified facts and news on the subject.
Trump responded on Twitter, accusing the platform of "interfering in the 2020 Presidential Election' and insisting that "as president, I will not allow this to happen.'
Its campaign manager, Brad Parscale, said the company's 'clear political bias' caused the campaign to withdraw "all of our Twitter advertising months ago."
The social media company banned all political advertising since November 2019.
Trump did not explain his threat Wednesday and the call to expand regulation seemed to go against old conservative principles about deregulation.
But some Trump allies, who have alleged bias on the part of tech companies, have questioned whether forums like Twitter and Facebook should continue to enjoy rules that take responsibility for being 'platforms'' under federal law, or be treated more like publishers, that could face content lawsuits.
Such guarantees have allowed unrestricted internet growth for more than two decades, but now some Trump allies are in favor of social media companies facing increased scrutiny.
"Big tech firms get a lot of money from the federal government,"' Republican Sen. Josh Hawley told Fox News. They receive special immunity from lawsuits and liability, which is worth billions of dollars to them each year. Why do they receive subsidies from federal taxpayers to censor conservatives, to censure people who criticize China?''
